Title: Forms to complete prior to enrollment
Body:
Forms to complete prior to enrollment

First, please read The FAQ for the Young Scholar Program and How do I enroll in Open University?.

Second, students under the age of 18 at the beginning of a quarter must complete and submit the following forms:

  • Waiver of Liability, Assumption of Risk & Indemnity Agreement
  • Authorization to Consent to Treatment of Minor
  • Adding Open University Student to GauchoSpace

Completed forms are required each quarter in which a student enrolls in Open University courses. All completed forms and payment are due at time of enrollment.

Title: Reporting Acts of Intolerance or Misconduct
Body:
Reporting Acts of Intolerance or Misconduct

If you notice acts of intolerance or form of misconduct that violates campus policies, we encourage you to report such behavior and to seek assistance for yourself or others from the following resources:

  • Hate Incident Response Coordinator: please visit the UCSB Office of Judicial Affairs page for online reporting or call (805) 893-4364
  • Campus Advocacy Resources Education (CARE), which confidential resources and information on reporting options for sexual violence, sexual assault, abusive relationships, and stalking: Student Resource Building or call (805) 893-4613 for the 24-hour advocacy line
  • UCSB Police Department: call (805) 893-3446 (or dial 9-1-1 in an emergency)
  • Isla Vista Foot Patrol: call (805) 681-4179 (or dial 9-1-1 in an emergency)

Title: No Smoking Policy
Body:
No Smoking Policy

As of January 2014, the entire University of California system is smoke-free and tobacco-free. Smoking, the use of smokeless tobacco products, e-cigarettes, and unregulated products is not allowed on UC-owned or leased properties.

Title: Is your Child Life Program Accredited?
Body:
Is your Child Life Program Accredited?

Yes, UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) is fully accredited by the WASC Senior College & University Commission (WSCUC). All courses in the program are approved for professional-level, post-graduate credit. This type of credit is typically recognized by government and industry for full or partial tuition funding or reimbursement. Course units and/or continuing education units (CEU) values are listed with the course descriptions. UCSB's current accreditation, please see: UCSB WASC Senior College and University Commission description from the Office of the Executive Vice Chancellor.

Title: Fees for Young Scholars
Body:
Fees for Young Scholars

For high school students, the non-refundable registration fee of $155 for taking UCSB courses through Open University is WAIVED.

In addition, children of eligible faculty and staff will receive a 15% discount. (as defined by UCSB for employee benefits). Discounts must be requested at the time of enrollment (a copy of the staff ID card must accompany the enrollment), and will not be applied retroactively. 

All other per unit fees and deadlines are listed here.

Title: ECON X499.1 can be substituted with ECON 134A
Body:
ECON X499.1 can be substituted with ECON 134A

Once your final grade is posted in GOLD, please email us at help@professional.ucsb.edu to inform us that you would like to substitute ECON 134A for ECON X499.1. Please attach an unofficial transcript to your request so we can verify your final grade. Please note that you must receive a grade of "C" or better in order for the course to be eligible for this substitution.

Title: How do I enroll in a Professional Certificate Program?
Body:
How do I enroll in a Professional Certificate Program?

To enroll in a Professional Certificate Program, begin by clicking the "Apply Now" button, which is located on the top right of each certificate page. This link takes you to the application where you create a student profile and pay the application fee. If you meet the program prerequisites you will receive a letter of acceptance by e-mail. (If you chose to apply after you have enrolled and/or completed courses, you will need to log in to your current student profile, add the application to your cart, and pay the fee.)

Title: Why Big Interview?
Body:
Why Big Interview?

Whether you are going on your very first interview or you are an experienced interviewee, Big Interview is available 24/7 to provide a self-guided journey through must-know questions and 1000+ industry-specific questions.

  • Practice Out Loud with Expert Advice - One of the best secrets to interview success is to verbalize your answers before your big day. Candidates who practice out loud are more likely to speak in a clear and coherent format when it is time to talk about your experiences, skills, knowledge, interests, and goals.
  • Prepare for Common Questions and Specialized Questions - Get yourself ready to answer the most commonly asked questions and the more targeted questions for interviews in a range of fields and industries.
  • Become Comfortable with Any Interview Format - Learn how to land the job with Big Interview's powerful video tutorials and interview practice software for virtual, phone, and in-person interviews.
  • Develop Your STARS Stories - Use the virtual platform to create, enhance, and save your best career stories in Situation-Task-Action-Result-So What? format to help you provide strong examples.

‚Ä¢Choose From Two Learning Tracks - Big Interview gives you both Fast Track and Mastery Track systems of lessons and virtual interview practice.

Title: Requirements for Completing a PCP or PSA
Body:
Requirements for Completing a PCP or PSA

Each Professional and Continuing Education program includes a different set of requirements, which are defined on the Program Course Schedule matrix located on each certificate page. All programs have specific course requirements, which include mandatory courses and/or elective course options. The matrix indicates how many total units are required and includes sections of what courses are required and which elective courses you can choose from to meet the program requirements. To earn a professional certificate you must apply and be accepted as a certificate candidate, and you must successfully complete each course requirement. (This typically includes earning a "C" or better for each course but please check each individual Program page for details.)

Title: Quarterly Email - Grades & Transcripts
Body:
Quarterly Email - Grades & Transcripts

Dear International Student,

As we near the end of the quarter, I want to take this opportunity to send you some information to help you understand when to expect grades and how to order your Official Transcript.

Grades
Grades for your courses will be submitted by your instructor(s) within 1-2 weeks after your final class session for each course. Sometimes, instructors inform students of their grades by email or by some other method. However, grades are official only after they are received by our UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) offices and recorded and approved into our enrollment system by our Registrar. If, while logged in to your student portal, you see that any one of your courses indicates "In Progress," it means that we have not yet received your grade from the instructor. Grades are provided for courses, not programs, so you will see the words "In Progress" next to the name of program; XLRN 832.XX University Immersion Program.

Official Transcripts
Your final Official Transcript will include all courses enrolled in and completed while here at UCSB PaCE. This will include any courses for which you received a letter "P" for Pass. Please visit our Help Center for instructions on how to purchase and order an Official Transcript. When you get to the point where you select a shipping option, please keep in mind that "Standard Processing" is regular postal mail and not track-able. "International Priority" is sent using FedEx, mailed next business day and we also provide a tracking number. Caution: Do not create a duplicate student profile. If you cannot login to your student profile or you can log in but do not see any courses, please contact student services at help@professional.ucb.edu.

Unofficial Transcript
Please visit our Help Center for instructions on how to get an Unofficial Transcript.

Please let us know if you have any questions by sending an email to help@professional.ucsb.edu.

I truly hope you enjoyed your experience while here in Santa Barbara and wish you all safe travels and much success in your future endeavors.

Kind regards,

Title: J-1 Scholar Application Process
Body:
J-1 Scholar Application Process

Welcome to UCSB as a J-1 visitor scholar or executive. Here are the best steps to take for enrollment in your program, and attainment of your visa:

1. Complete our online application and make sure to include all supplemental documents.

2. Upon acceptance, you will receive an acceptance email and instructions to enter specific information on your OISS DS-2019 portal.(J-1 applications typically take longer to process.)

3. Once this is done, we will send your acceptance packet directly to you. This packet will include your original letter of acceptance, instructions and information, and DS-2019. You will need these documents to get your J-1 Visa.

4. Make a visa appointment at your local U.S. Embassy or Consulate and pay the I-901 SEVIS fee. (The earlier the better!)

5. Successfully complete your visa interview.

6. Enjoy sunny Santa Barbara! You can enter the U.S. no earlier than 30 days before your DS-2019 program start date.

Title: Open University Roadmap: Technology Management
Body:
Open University Roadmap: Technology Management

If you need to enroll into TMP (Technology Management Program) classes offered through UC Santa Barbara Division of Professional and Continuing Education, follow the instructions below: 

  1. Send an e-mail directly to a TMP academic advisor expressing your interest in specific classes. 
  2. Attend the first day of class and introduce yourself as an Open University student.
  3. The instructor will sign the form (below) and will direct you to the department for the advisor to sign as well.
  4. The advisor will sign Open University (OU) Application/Authorization forms and send them directly to the Student Services Office, Kerr Hall 2166.
  5. You can pick up your signed OU Authorization forms at the Student Services Office.

Title: What are the steps to EMT certification?
Body:
What are the steps to EMT certification?

This article is designed to be an overview of how to become a certified EMT.  The process will be explained chronologically so that it can be used as a check sheet to become a certified Santa Barbara County EMT. 

  1. Successfully complete authorized EMT course
  • Obtain 80% overall in class AND 80% on the final exam.
  • Obtain Course Completion Award (CCA) from UCSB.

 

  1. Register with the National Registry of EMTs at nremt.org Obtain your account. 
  • This can be done at any time however; we recommend you wait until the last four weeks of class.
  • EMT course instructor will verify course completion which allows you to take:
    • National Registry Practical Exam- This exam is held at UCSB the weekend after the final exam. While the practical can be taken anywhere, we HIGHLY recommend you take it at UCSB.
    • Cognitive Exam- This is a computer based test and it is given through Pearson-Vue Testing Centers(vue.com) the closest sites are in Santa Maria or Westlake, CA. This exam can be taken before or after the practical exam.
  • National Registry Certification- Once you complete the cognitive and practical exams, you become nationally registered. This certification does NOT allow you work as an EMT. You must become CA State licensed.

 

  1. Apply for your CA State License through Santa Barbara County Certification
  • The State of CA defers to all counties to certify EMTs.
  • Santa Barbara County Process: Obtain an application from SB County EMS Agency. http://www.countyofsb.org/phd/ems.  Use this website for detailed step-by-step certification process.
  • Obtain Live Scan fingerprint analysis (must be done for the EMS agency where you are certifying)
  • Turn in application, have picture taken and obtain County certification.

 

  1. Apply for California Ambulance Certification
  • Obtain valid Class B Driver's License.
  • Obtain application for Ambulance Driver's Certificate.
  • Take written test
  • Obtain Live Scan for DMV
  • Obtain a medical exam and submit exam results to DMV.

Title: How do students get their Open University grades included on their official UCSB transcripts?
Body:
How do students get their Open University grades included on their official UCSB transcripts?

To order a UCSB Professional and Continuing Education official transcript, follow the steps in How to order a Transcript.

UCSB Professional and Continuing Education does not automatically send Open University grades to the UCSB Office of Admissions. Once the transcript has been ordered and received by the Office of Admissions, official UCSB transcripts will include grades for both Open University and regular session courses.

When placing your order via Parchment, if you choose to mail a printed copy of your PaCE official transcript to the UCSB Office of Admissions, please use one of these options:

Newly admitted, current, and returning undergraduate students should mail transcripts to:

UCSB Office of Admissions
1210 Cheadle Hall
Santa Barbara, CA 93106-2014

Current graduate students should mail transcripts to:

UCSB Graduate Division
3117 Cheadle Hall
Santa Barbara, CA 93106-2070

When placing your order via Parchment, if you choose to send your PaCE official transcript electronically to the UCSB Office of Admissions, then please send it to: admissions@sa.ucsb.edu

Title: Should I take Medical Humanities electives before or after PaCe courses INT X410 and INT X411?
Body:
Should I take Medical Humanities electives before or after PaCe courses INT X410 and INT X411?

Ideally one would take PaCE course INT X410, Introduction to Medical Humanities, before electives. That said, there's no formal sequence in which electives and PaCE courses must be taken.

Title: How Do I Prove my Residency?
Body:
How Do I Prove my Residency?

First, complete the GROW Application, where you will be prompted to upload proof of residency. Possible documentation includes:

  • Student ID Card from Allan Hancock College
  • Driver's License (or other government-issued identification documentation)
  • Utility bill (with official name and current address)
  • Rental, Lease, or Mortgage bill (Rental/Lease need to be dated and signed)
  • Voter registration confirmation letter

Please note: Once your proof of residency is approved, it is valid indefinitely.

Title: How do I apply for Optional Practical Training?
Body:
How do I apply for Optional Practical Training?

How to apply for Optional Practical Training (OPT):

1. You do not need a job offer to apply. However, once you find a qualifying job, you must notify the Immigration Advisor at UCSB International Programs by contacting them at the Help Center.

2. The earliest you can apply for OPT is 90 days before your program completion date and no later than 60 days after your program end date as indicated on your I-20.

3. You must complete UCSB International Program's OPT Form Request first to initiate the OPT request process. UCSB International Program's Immigration Advisor will make a request in the government database for your work authorization. The Advisor will provide you with a new, OPT-notated I-20.

4. Gather all documents in PDF and supporting materials to submit with the application for employment authorization, which will include the following:

  • A copy of I-94 from https://i94.cbp.dhs.gov/I94/#/home (Get most recent I-94)
  • A copy of a valid passport (copy of the BIO page)
  • A copy of the F1 visa, if applicable (visa page)
  • A photocopy of your OPT-notated I-20 (don't forget to sign it!)
  • Photocopies of any previous Employment Authorization Documents (EAD), if applicable
  • Two identical photographs (photograph instructions are found on the Form I-765 instructions under Required Documentation)
  • The $410 filing fee (payable to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security - have your credit card ready)

5. Once the Immigration Advisor sends your I20 with the OPT noted, you must file Form I-765 "Application for Employment Authorization" within 30 days from the date on the I20. Form will be filled out online, no need to download it as a PDF.

 

6. Go to the USCIS website to start your application. Create an account and follow the instructions. Once you complete your profile, choose "Form I-765 - Application for Employment Authorization" to be filed. You can upload all the documents online through the USCIS portal. 


7. Lastly, final OPT decisions are made completely by the US government. UCSB International Programs is not involved in this process. Please DO NOT leave the U.S. if your OPT is not approved yet.

 

8. You should also report your status to the SEVP student portal. Students who fail to report or enter their information in the Portal in a timely manner or otherwise fail to comply with their reporting requirements may be deemed to be in violation of their nonimmigrant status. If you have found work that is related to your studies, you are responsible for reporting your employment to us and explaining, in writing, how the job relates to your major area of study so that the information can be reported in SEVIS or otherwise retained. 


Feel free to download the Optional Practical Training Guidelines for more details.

Title: Campus Police
Body:
Campus Police

If you have an emergency on campus, please call the UCSB Police Department. Dial 9-1-1 from any campus telephone or from the yellow call boxes on campus with a blue light on top. Your call will go directly to the UCSB police dispatcher for appropriate action.

If you need to reach the UCSB Police Department for a nonemergency, contact them at (805) 893-3446.

Title: What are the prerequisites for enrolling in the BCBA/BCaBA programs?
Body:
What are the prerequisites for enrolling in the BCBA/BCaBA programs?

  • BCBA requirements outlined by BACB

To be eligible for this area of certification, students must already have obtained a graduate degree (i.e., Masters or higher) OR are concurrently earning a graduate degree. For information about the BCBA Examination and requirements, click here. Candidates must complete all 7 courses with letter grades of "C" or better to fulfill the coursework requirements. Lastly, to comply with BACB regulations you must be a resident or citizen in the following countries: US, Canada, Australia, and the UK.  For more information, click here. 

  • BCaBA requirements outlined by the BACB

To be eligible for this area of a certificate, students must already have obtained a Bachelor's degree OR are concurrently earning that degree. To comply with BACB regulations you must be a resident or citizen in the following countries: US, Canada, Australia, and the UK.  For more information, click here.

Title: Computer Labs and Internet Access
Body:
Computer Labs and Internet Access

Modern instructional facilities at UCSB provide high-speed Internet access and a wide variety of software applications for Open University students. Instructional Labs on campus are available during open access/drop-in hours. If you wish to use this facility, you must present your Student ID # (available from the Student Portal) to the lab attendant.

Title: Can I Pay at the Door of the First Class Meeting?
Body:
Can I Pay at the Door of the First Class Meeting?

No, fees are not taken at the door. You should be sure to enroll before the first class meeting. Enrollment options are available on the Registration Information page. If you have trouble enrolling before the first meeting, contact Student Services at (805) 893-4200 or help@professional.ucsb.edu them for assistance. Last-minute enrollees are required to bring their confirmation number on the first day for evidence of payment, as they may not be on the class list.

Body:
When are courses being offered?

The Strategic Investments Program courses will be offered on a rolling basis over the Fall, Winter, and Spring quarters. 

Please note that the most current information about the course schedule and cadence can be found on the Strategic Investments Certificate page.

Title: What types of infractions on a criminal background check disqualify me from becoming an EMT?
Body:
What types of infractions on a criminal background check disqualify me from becoming an EMT?

Any individual with a DUI (driving under the influence), felony conviction, and/or failure to pay child support, etc. can and will likely be disqualified from taking the EMT course. If you are not sure, contact the Program Director for review/approval.

Title: What should I do if I receive an Open University enrollment form?
Body:
What should I do if I receive an Open University enrollment form?

Please do the following if you receive an Open University enrollment form:

  1. Review the form to ensure it is the correct class, and your name is listed in the 1st section.
  2. Review the attached transcript to ensure that academic experience is relevant and satisfactory for performance in the course.
  3. You will have the option to either 'Approve' or 'Deny' the form. Please choose one option. If space is available in the course, and all prerequisites are met, please click 'Approve.' If space is not available or academic experience is unsatisfactory, please click 'Deny'
  4. Choose 'Finish' at the bottom of the form.
  5. A completed form will automatically be sent to our office for official enrollment, or to notify the student the request has been denied.
  6. If you approved the enrollment, the student will send another form with their NetID. Please manually add the student to the course site in Canvas as soon as possible.
  7. Finally, the student will show at the bottom of your roster within 3-5 business days.

If you have any questions at any moment, please contact help@professional.ucsb.edu. We will respond within 24 business hours.

Thank you for considering our students for enrollment!

Title: What Courses Are Eligible for GROW Financial Aid?
Body:
What Courses Are Eligible for GROW Financial Aid?

Everything listed on the GROW webpage is eligible for a discount.

Please note: Courses not listed do not qualify.

Title: What kind of technology do I need for the online courses?
Body:
What kind of technology do I need for the online courses?

No additional software is needed. All you need is access to a computer and Internet access. UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) uses Canvas, the leading LMS among major public research universities. You log into Canvas to participate in course discussions, access readings, take quizzes, upload assignments, etc. In some cases, you can track your grades for your course. For more information, please visit How to Access courses in Canvas

Official grades are posted in your student profile on UCSB Professional and Continuing Education website, under "My Enrollment History." You can also order an official transcript by following these steps.

Title: How do I find the courses I may take through Open University?
Body:
How do I find the courses I may take through Open University?

Current and recent past course offerings are listed by quarter in the Schedule of Classes.

Additional information about future UCSB regular session course offerings can be found in the UCSB General Catalog (click on "Academic Department Directory," select your department, and then click "Courses" to view course listings) and in the specific department listings on the main UCSB website.

Title: How do I get the Eye Tracking Calibration tool to work properly?
Body:
How do I get the Eye Tracking Calibration tool to work properly?

Before you record videos in Big Interview, the system will prompt you to look at four corners of your screen using the Eye Tracking Calibration tool.

If you encounter difficulties when using this tool, we recommend brightening the amount of light on your face, keeping your camera near eye level, or temporarily removing any eyewear.

Title: Course Numbers
Body:
Course Numbers

XSB1 to XSB199 Undergraduate Open University courses

Courses numbered XSB1 to XSB199 are UCSB regular session undergraduate courses open for enrollment by students through UCSB Professional and Continuing Education. Courses numbered XSB1 to XSB99 are lower division (freshman/sophomore); those numbered XSB100 to XSB199 are upper division (junior/senior). 

XSB200 to XSB299 and XSB400 to XSB499 Graduate Open University courses

Courses numbered XSB200 to XSB299 and XSB400 to XSB499 are UCSB regular session graduate courses open for enrollment by students through UCSB Professional and Continuing Education. Note: UCSB graduate students may not take coursework through Open University that can otherwise be completed through normal registration. Consult the chapter "Graduate Education at UCSB" in the UCSB General Catalog.

X1 to X199

Courses numbered X1 to X99 are typically recognized as undergraduate lower division (freshman/sophomore); those numbered X100 to X199 are typically recognized as undergraduate upper division (junior/senior). These courses are structured in accordance to requirements for UCSB undergraduate courses, but are not equivalent to regular session courses. 

X300 to X399

Courses numbered X300 to X399 are professional level credit courses in the field of education. These classes are designed for teachers and prospective teachers. The major emphasis in these courses is on teaching methods and materials, curriculum, philosophical and sociological foundations of education, and educational problems and law.

X400 to X499

Courses numbered X400 to X399 are professional-level (post-baccalaureate) credit courses and lecture series in fields other than education. While most of these courses offer special opportunities for professionals and paraprofessionals, many courses are of general interest.

X800 to X899

Courses numbered X800 to X899 are noncredit seminars that provide opportunities to pursue intellectual, professional, civic, and cultural interests. These courses are generally designated with Continuing Education Units (CEUs), which are a universally recognized means of measuring and recording noncredit, postsecondary-level study. One CEU is awarded for every 10 contact or classroom hours of participation, and less than 10 hours is shown as a fractional CEU. (For example, an eight-hour conference earns 0.8 CEU.)

When employers, relicensure agencies, and other similar authorities require a specified number of instruction hours for career advancement, CEUs provide a useful record of noncredit study. 

Open University

Certain UCSB regular session academic courses ‚Äîundergraduate and graduate (XSB1 to XSB499)‚Äî are open to the public. Enrollment is subject to the following restrictions:

  • Space availability
  • Consent of instructor and academic department 
  • Applicable admission requirements and prerequisites

Note: Open University is available fall, winter, and spring quarters only.

Please see the Open University page for detailed information on the following policies and procedures:

  • Eligibility
  • Enrollment authorization
  • Petitions
  • Enrollment limits
  • Payment procedure
  • Course fees
  • Payment deadlines
  • Dropping courses/withdrawal from Open University
  • Fee refunds
  • Grades
  • Degree and degree credit
  • Student privileges
  • Student conduct
  • Disability services
  • Tax information

For information about UCSB regular session academic courses available to Open University students, see the UCSB Schedule of Classes. For information about UCSB academic courses, prerequisites, and major requirements, please see the UCSB General Catalog.

Title: Which UCSB Courses Are Available to Young Scholars Program Students?
Body:
Which UCSB Courses Are Available to Young Scholars Program Students?

Students can enroll in undergraduate courses on the UCSB campus. Enrollment is based on space availability. Once confirmed for Young Scholars Program, students will follow the same enrollment procedures as students enrolled in UCSB PaCE's Open University program.

Title: In Which High School Year Should a Student Apply for Young Scholars Program?
Body:
In Which High School Year Should a Student Apply for Young Scholars Program?

Most students are nominated in their junior or senior year; however, it is not uncommon to have sophomores nominated.

Title: What is the drop/refund policy of International Reporting Trip?
Body:
What is the drop/refund policy of International Reporting Trip?

Given the special nature of the program, requests for refunds of tuition will not be granted, with the exception of certain unusual circumstances beyond the student's control, such as the denial of a student visa or a medical emergency substantiated by Student's medical provider note.

You are required to inform UCSB's Professional and Continuing Education Student Services staff immediately of changes to your status, withdrawal, or drop-out of the program. Submit your written request for an exception to the refund policy to help@professional.ucsb.edu. PaCE's staff will notify you whether or not your request has been granted.

Title: When and how do I clear course prerequisites?
Body:
When and how do I clear course prerequisites?

For UCSB regular session courses, bring your transcript (in English) to the first class session for review by the instructor, as requested. Prerequisites are listed in the UCSB Schedule of Classes and the UCSB General Catalog (by department).

Title: When and how can I enroll in UCSB Academic courses?
Body:
When and how can I enroll in UCSB Academic courses?

You can enroll in academic courses during the enrollment period of each quarter. There is no opportunity to enroll in academic courses pre-arrival.

During the first 3 weeks of the quarter, students visit the classes they want to take. You can digitally send the Enrollment Authorization Form to get enrollment approval. For the correct contact for each department, please review the list here. 

When the form is completed, it will automatically be sent to our office for formal enrollment. Because you pay a per-quarter flat tuition fee, there will be no individual course payments.

To recap:

  1. Search for UCSB Academic courses in the quarter of study.
  2. Send your enrollment form to the correct recipient for approval (department advisor, or Professor.)
  3. Once approved, you will be formally enrolled by our Customer Service Team and notified via email.
  4. Only after you receive the email from our Customer Service Team confirming your enrollment, you can send your Canvas form to the professor to be added to the course site. Please do not send the Canvas form to the professor until you receive the enrollment confirmation email from us. If you have never logged into Canvas before, please log into Canvas first, using your UCSBNetID and password. This creates your account.

Note: Spaces are not guaranteed and are on a space-available basis.

Title: How to order a Transcript
Body:
How to order a Transcript

Your final official transcript will include all courses enrolled in and completed while here at UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE). This will include any courses for which you received a letter "P" for pass.

We do not offer unofficial transcripts but we offer both electronic and printed official transcripts via Parchment, our online transcript ordering service.

1) Please log into the Student Portal to check that all your grades have been posted in your Student Profile before placing an order. Click on "My Enrollment History" under the "Completed Courses" tab, you will find your final grades. If all your final grades are posted, please proceed with placing your order. If a grade is not posted in your Student Profile, the course in question will not be listed on your official transcript.

2) Please click Order Records below:

3) If you are a first time user of Parchment, you will have to create an account with Parchment. Click on "New Learner Account".

4) Fill out all the required fields, click on "Sign Up" and then follow the prompts to place your order.

5) If you have an existing account with Parchment, click on "Existing User Account", enter your email address and password. Click on "Sign In" and then follow the prompts to place your order.

 

Pricing*

Electronic official transcript: $15

Paper official transcript: $17.50 (USPS Domestic Mail)

 

Typical Paper Transcript Shipping Charges

USPS International Mail $2.50

FedEx Overnight Domestic $22.50

FedEx International $45.00

 

* Payments will be made directly to Parchment and will not be listed in your PaCE Student Account.

Title: Will INT X410 or INT X411 courses count toward my academic load?

Will INT X410 or INT X411 courses count toward my academic load?

No, PaCE courses are "professional" units (X400s) and do not count toward your academic load and academic degree requirements.

Title: BCBA and BCaBA Course Attestation Process
Body:
BCBA and BCaBA Course Attestation Process

Congratulations on completing the UCSB PaCE's BCBA/BCaBA Program! You are one step closer to becoming a Certified Behavior Analyst.  Before our VCS Coordinator can submit your Coursework Attestation to BACB, you will need to do the following:

  1. Complete the UCSB PaCE's BCBA or BCaBA Application and pay the Application Fee. 
  2. Complete the BCBA or BCaBA DocuSign. 

The DocuSign consists of two important documents: (1) Release of information and (2) BACB's Coursework Attestation Form. 

In the Attestation Form, you are responsible for inputting your personal information. The DocuSign will prompt you through the different fields you need to complete. 

Once you have completed and signed the DocuSign, our VCS Coordinator will complete the Attestation Form and submit it to BACB within 72 hours. 

Lastly, YOU are responsible for submitting your own official transcript. UCSB PaCE WILL NOT submit your transcript to BACB. Please follow the instructions on how to order a PaCE official transcript here.

If you have any questions please contact our PaCE Customer Support at help@professional.ucsb.edu. Our office is open Monday through Friday, from 9am to 5pm PST.

Title: Is BACB the same as ABAI?
Body:
Is BACB the same as ABAI?

  • BACB (Behavior Analyst Certification Board) is the board governing the BCBA/BCaBA certification exam.  BACB's goal is to "meet professional credentialing needs identified by behavior analysts, governments, and consumers of behavior analysis services." 
  • ABAI (Association for Behavior Analysis International) is "the primary membership organization for those interested in the philosophy, science, application, and teaching of behavior analysis." ABAI is responsible for verifying university programs that fulfill BACB's coursework requirements.

Title: Religious Accommodation and Observance
Body:
Religious Accommodation and Observance

Religious Accommodation

In accordance with California State Education Code section 92640, it is UCSB policy that an instructor will make a reasonable attempt to accommodate to your needs in the case of serious incompatibility between your religious creed and a scheduled test or examination. If you look at the course calendar and find a scheduling incompatibility, keep in mind of the following:

  1. Accommodation for alternative examination dates will be worked out directly and on an individual basis between you and the instructor involved.
  2. You should make a religious accommodation request during the first two weeks of an academic term, or as soon as possible after a particular examination date is announced by the instructor.
  3. Students or faculty with questions may contact the associate dean of the appropriate school.

Religious Observance

You may also observe religious holidays that are not official university holidays. Observance of these holidays may impact your test or examination schedule. When looking over your course's calendar, it is important to note that the date(s) religious holidays fall on may vary by year. Particularly with Muslim Holy Days, observance begins at sundown on the preceding day. Although Muslim Holy Days are always on the same day of the Islamic calendar, the date on the Gregorian calendar varies from year to year (since the Gregorian calendar is a solar calendar and the Islamic calendar is a lunar calendar). This difference in calendars means Muslim Holy Days move in the Gregorian calendar approximately 11 days every year. The date of a Muslim Holy Day may also vary from country to country, depending on whether the moon has been sighted or not.

Title: Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Project Management
Body:
Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Project Management

A certificate is awarded upon completion of the 5 required courses totaling 20 units (or 180 hours of instruction), listed in the Program Schedule each with a letter grade of "C" / "Pass" or better. All requirements must be completed within five (5) years after the student enrolls in their first course. Students not pursuing a certificate are welcome to take as many individual courses as they wish.

There are no prerequisites for courses in this certificate nor is a bachelor's degree required.

It is recommended that students take TMP X450 - Introduction to Project Management, first.

To become an official candidate in the program, students need only register in one of the courses in the approved curriculum.

Request for Certificate Release

Application Fee $95.00

If all the Certificate requirements have been met, after your request is processed, you will receive an email notification from Parchment with a digital copy of your Certificate. A printed copy will be mailed via regular US Postal Service to the mailing address provided in your PaCE Student Profile 8-10 business days after receipt of the digital copy.

The $95 Certificate Release Fee is non-refundable. This Fee is required in order to receive a copy of your Certificate.

Click here to request your Certificate Release.

Title: General Inquiry about UIP - response
Body:
General Inquiry about UIP - response

Hello from Santa Barbara! Thank you for your interest in UCSB Professional and Continuing Education.

UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) is a division of UCSB which allows visiting international students the opportunity to enroll in academic courses offered by the main campus of UCSB and/or in professional level courses offered directly by UCSB PaCE.

You will first need to apply to our University Immersion Program (UIP) for international students. You can find information and our ISP application here. To do this, you will fill out our ISP Application and submit your application along with all required supplemental documents as indicated on the first page/cover page of the application under the column University Immersion Program (UIP).  The deadline for applications is 6 weeks before the start date of the program. The Winter quarter 2019 starts on January 4, 2019 and the Spring quarter 2019 starts on March 29, 2019.

Once you are accepted, we will send you an I-20 (certificate of eligibility) document which you will use to apply for an F-1 Student Visa at a local U.S. Consulate or Embassy.  As an F-1 Student Visa holder, you will be required to enroll in a minimum of 12 units (undergraduate and/or professional-level courses) or 8 units (graduate courses) each quarter in order to maintain your F-1 visa status.

Below is the link to the UCSB Schedule of Classes class finder which lists all academic courses offered by main campus UCSB for a specific quarter.

https://my.sa.ucsb.edu/Public/curriculum/coursesearch.aspx

To view professional level courses offered by UCSB PaCE, please go to our website home page and click on 'Certificates'.  If you see an area that interests you (Marketing, for example) you will click on this certificate program to view the individual courses offered as part of the certificate program. Please note that students are not required to complete an entire certificate program.  You are welcome to enroll in an individual course of interest included under a certificate program without completing the entire certificate program.

Fees for our UIP program are as follows:
Application Fee (one time): $200
Program Fee (each quarter): $1275
Student Services Fee (each quarter): $920

Individual course fees are in addition to the fees indicated above.  

When it is time to submit your application, all application documents should be sent as scanned attachments to the following email address: apply@professional.ucsb.edu.   Again, the application deadline is 6 weeks before the start of the program.  

I hope this information is helpful. Please feel free to contact me with any additional questions you may have and I will be happy to assist.

Title: Can I use Big Interview to get reviewed by friends, family, and mentors?
Body:
Can I use Big Interview to get reviewed by friends, family, and mentors?

Absolutely! You can send an individual video or series of videos you record for an Assignment to friends, family, mentors, and other people in your personal network by clicking the Send button and inputting their email address. Upon sending your request, each Reviewer will receive an email invitation to provide feedback on your recorded videos through Big Interview. You will get an email update once they have submitted their Review.

Title: Do I need a California driver's license to drive in California?
Body:
Do I need a California driver's license to drive in California?

You do not need to get a California driver's license if you hold a driver's license from your home country. California recognizes foreign driver licenses for international, nonresident students.

Title: Transferring Courses, Dropping Courses and Withdrawal Procedures
Body:
Transferring Courses, Dropping Courses and Withdrawal Procedures

Transfers

PaCE Courses

You may submit a Transfer request for any PaCE Course (Classroom, HyFlex and Online) prior to the published drop deadline of the course you are currently enrolled in. Please follow the Transfer request process below:

  • Transfer requests must be made before the published drop deadline. 
  • Requests may be submitted in writing by contacting help@professional.ucsb.edu. Please include your name, student number and the course number and title for both the course you want to transfer from and into.
  • Approvals for Transfer requests are based on course and space availability and the scheduled course start date.
  • Any difference in course fees are assessed and due at the time of the transfer.

Withdrawals

PaCE Courses

PaCE Credit Courses (X1 to X199)

It is the student's responsibility to petition to withdraw from a course in which they are enrolled. The Petition for Withdrawal form must be submitted with the instructor's signature no later than 4pm on the Friday of the fourth week of instruction. A "W" or withdraw, is recorded on the transcript in this case.
Students who stop attending and who do not formally withdraw by notifying the UCSB PaCE Student Services Office in writing will have an NP or F recorded, depending on the course number and grading option.

PaCE Credit Courses (X300 to X499)

Students who wish to withdraw from a credit course may do so until the last class session without penalty providing they notify UCSB Extension Student Services Office in writing and the instructor of the course. A "No Credit" (NC) will be recorded in this case.

PaCE Noncredit Courses (X800 to X899)

Students who wish to withdraw from a noncredit course may do so until the last class session by notifying the UCSB Extension Student Services Office in writing. Special Withdrawal Policies: These are noted in the course descriptions and special program announcements throughout the publications.

Drops/Refunds

A minimum $40 non-refundable administrative fee per course is charged for ALL refunds except when courses are cancelled, discontinued, or rescheduled. ALWAYS check the course page for specific drop policy stipulations and published deadlines.

If you who wish to cancel your enrollment and you are eligible for a refund of course fees (less the $40 non-refundable administrative fee per course), you should notify UCSB PaCE as soon as possible and before the published drop deadline through the Student Portal.

Log in to your Student Portal. Navigate to "My Enrollment History (Current Courses)". Select the course you would like to drop. On the right side, under "Actions and Status," select "Request Drop". You will receive an e-mail confirmation within 1-2 business days after your drop request is processed.

Alternatively, please submit a written drop request to help@professional.ucsb.edu by the published drop deadline date or fees are automatically forfeited. 

NOTE: Be sure to include your name, date, course title, course number, a daytime phone number, and your student ID number.

Programs with Specific Drop Policy Stipulations

  • For EMT Course Drop and Withdrawal Policy, please review this article.
  • For CPA Licensure Prep Summer Program Drop and Withdrawal Policy, please review this article.
  • For Strategic Investments Drop and Withdrawal Policy, please review this article.

Refund Eligibility for Courses with 1-6 Meetings

A full refund is given less the $40 non-refundable administrative fee per course if notice is received five days or more before the start date of the course. A 50% refund is given less the $40 non-refundable administrative fee per course if notice is received one to four days before the start date of the course. No refunds are given after the course begins.

Refund Eligibility for Courses with 7 or More Meetings and Online Asynchronous Courses

A full refund is given (less the $40 non-refundable administrative fee per course) if notice is received by 11:59 pm on the second Sunday from the course start date. No refunds are given if notice is received after the refund deadlines.

Fees paid by check are refunded with a check. Allow 4-8 weeks from the date the refund is requested to receive the check. Fees paid using VISA, MasterCard, or Discover will be credited back to that card within 5-7 business days once a drop request is received. 

Refund Exceptions

Exceptions to these policies are considered only under the most unusual circumstances. All exceptions must be submitted in writing and be accompanied by any supporting documents (such as a doctor's note).

A Student Services representative will contact you as to the outcome of your request. Refunds are not granted if a student chooses to disregard the course prerequisite(s) and finds he/she must drop the course after the refund deadline. If you have stopped attending a credit course and are receiving a refund, you will automatically be deleted from the course. Otherwise, if you stop attending, you must officially withdraw by notifying PaCE in writing.

These policies and procedures do not pertain to Open University courses. Please refer to the current Open University policies for details.

Title: How do I Earn and Receive a Digital Badge?
Body:
How do I Earn and Receive a Digital Badge?

By completing selected skill-oriented courses, you will earn a digital badge. You don&'t need to do anything: you will receive an email within 2-3 weeks of completion to inform you that your badge is available for download from your Parchment account. 

Make sure to add a mobile number to your PaCE Student Account  in order to receive a SMS notification. You will have permanent, online access to a secure digital version of all your badges and credentials. Share your badges online securely!

Title: What does VCS stand for?
Body:
What does VCS stand for?

VCS stands for Verified Course Sequence. ABAI thoroughly reviews approved university programs on a yearly basis in order to ensure that each program fulfills BACB's course requirements.

Title: How Do I Access my ucsb.edu email address (U-Mail)?
Body:
How Do I Access my ucsb.edu email address (U-Mail)?

Your U-Mail address is your UCSBNet ID followed by @ucsb.edu and the password is the same as the one for your UCSBNetID.

  1. Make sure you are enrolled in DUO multi-factor-authentication(MFA). Detailed DUO instructions can be found here. If you have questions or need help in enrolling in DUO, please submit a ticket here or call (805) 893-HELP (x4357). Hours of operation are 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. PST, Monday through Friday.
  2. Go to http://www.umail.ucsb.edu click the "U-Mail WebAccess" button or go to https://mail.google.com/a/ucsb.edu
  3. Type in your UCSBnetID (for example: dsmith@ucsb.edu). 

4. Type in your UCSBnetID password you created when activating your UCSBNetID

Title: How can I find out if I meet course prerequisites?
Body:
How can I find out if I meet course prerequisites?

You are responsible for meeting all the course prerequisites before enrolling in courses. Formal prerequisite clearance is required for some courses. Prerequisites ensure that you will have the necessary academic background for a course.

A. For UCSB Professional and Continuing Education courses with prerequisites, you must clear prerequisites with the instructor via e-mail before enrolling in courses. To clear prerequisites you must submit a request to Student Services. When you address the request to the instructor you should include the following:

  • Re: Prerequisite Clearance in the subject line
  • ID # and title of your desired course
  • Title and description (in English) of the course(s) taken at your home university that have similar content as the prerequisite for your desired course at UCSB
  • Your most recent transcript (in English)
  • Your name and e-mail address

Note: Send a separate request for each course with a prerequisite requirement. UCSB Professional and Continuing Education Student Services personnel will forward your request to the instructor and then let you know whether or not your request has been granted.

B. For UCSB regular session courses with prerequisites, see General Questions about Open University: When and How Do I Clear Course Prerequisites?.

Title: Should I try to improve my resume until it gets a score of 100?
Body:
Should I try to improve my resume until it gets a score of 100?

The scoring algorithm in VMock is intended to help you understand your resume's areas of improvement and suggest potential revisions.

 

Because no resume is ever "perfect" or "finished," your goal should NOT be to obtain a score of 100, but to make specific improvements strategically.

 

Once you have made some improvements based on the System Feedback and Targeted Feedback, and your resume has reached a score of 60 or higher, you are ready to request Network Feedback.

 

Network Feedback ensures that your resume reaches its full potential for a specific job target, with the assistance of a friend or mentor.

Title: What is GROW?
Body:
What is GROW?

GROW is a degree completion and professional development assistance initiative by UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (UCSB PaCE), exclusively for North Santa Barbara County, San Luis Obispo County and Kern County residents.

It is supported by a grant from the State of California and UC office of the President. Students are eligible for financial assistance once enrolled in GROW. To learn more, please visit the GROW program webpage.

Title: What is the drop/refund policy of STEP UPP?
Body:
What is the drop/refund policy of STEP UPP?

You are required to inform UCSB's Professional and Continuing Education Student Services staff immediately of any changes to your status, withdrawal, drop-out of the Step UPP program. Submit your written request to help@extension.ucsb.edu

Given the special nature of the program, requests for refunds of tuition and insurance fees will not be granted, with the exception of unusual circumstances beyond the student's control, such as the denial of a student visa.

In situations where the U.S. embassy or consulate has denied the applicant a Student (F-1) Visa, the denial letter from the embassy must be submitted to UCSB Professional and Continuing Education. A refund of the tuition and insurance fees will granted provided that notification is given at least 30 calendar days before the program start date.

Title: What is FOCUS® 2:
Body:
What is FOCUS® 2:

A Career & Education Planning System. Navigating important choices in college isn't easy. With courses to choose, and careers to pursue, the options can seem endless. For most students, this is a worthy cause for some self-reflection. FOCUS® 2 is available to you as a one-stop planning tool to help you clarify your goals by assessing key aspects of yourself.

Title: What is the testing procedure for EMT certification?
Body:
What is the testing procedure for EMT certification?

The UCSB EMT course prepares the student to take the National Registry of EMT's psychomotor and cognitive exam for EMT Certification. The course itself does not offer a certificate.

The psychomotor hands-on skills testing is provided on site near the end of the semester. The cognitive testing is delivered at a computer based testing lab off-site and is taken after the UCSB EMT course has been successfully completed. There is an additional fee for the cognitive testing. Once the National Registry EMT (NREMT) tests have been successfully passed, the student will receive their NREMT certification. They will then present their credentials to the county in California that they desire EMT certification and follow the state requirements for EMT certification.

Title: F-1 Visa Regulations for New and Continuing Students
Body:
F-1 Visa Regulations for New and Continuing Students

New F-1 students who choose to attempt entry to the U.S. must have an in-person component in their class schedule. Anyone attempting to enter the U.S. must have a valid entry visa and not be from a country subject to any current travel bans.

Continuing students have been authorized to take their full course load online. These students may enroll in online classes full-time through UCSB International Programs. Students will be able to maintain their visa status under these special circumstances.

All students are still expected to maintain the minimum unit load and comply with other regulatory requirements associated with their visa status unless otherwise authorized.

If you have any questions please email us at help@extension.ucsb.edu.

Title: IMPORTANT information for students who need to transition from the 4th Edition to the 5th Edition!
Body:
IMPORTANT information for students who need to transition from the 4th Edition to the 5th Edition!

 

Students who need to transition from the 4th edition to the 5th edition will need to take the following courses: ED X 309A.5, ED X 309B.5, and ED X 309C.5.  Also, please keep in mind that you will need to accrue an additional 500 supervised fieldwork hours. 

  • Q: Why do I need to take 3 more classes? 
  • A: Due to the new coursework requirements per BACB, we had to make some major readjustments to our courses. The three additional courses will cover new content that is required by the BACB. 
  • Q: I already took the research practicum courses. Does that not count? 
  • A: Again, we had to update our coursework and redistribute the content hours in order to meet BACB's 5th edition requirements. 
  • Q: Did any of your courses cover assessments?
  • A: If no, then you'll also need to take ED X 365.5

For more information, please click on this link.

Title: What is the deadline to submit my GROW Application?
Body:
What is the deadline to submit my GROW Application?

Please note that no Applications will be accepted after the first day of instructions (check the course start day on the Course page) for the quarter you are currently applying for.

If you have self-enrolled in a GROW eligible course prior to submitting an Application and your Application is approved prior to the first day of instructions, we will issue you a full refund and we will call you to enroll you again at the discounted GROW price.

Title: Withdrawal from Professional Credit Courses X1 to X199
Body:
Withdrawal from Professional Credit Courses X1 to X199

It is your responsibility to petition to withdraw from a course in which you are enrolled. The Petition for Withdrawal Form must be submitted with the instructor's signature no later than 4 p.m. on the Friday of the fourth week of instruction. A "W" (Withdraw) grade is recorded on the transcript in this case.

If you stop attending and do not formally withdraw by notifying Student Services at help@professional.ucsb.edu, you will have an "NP" or "F" grade recorded, depending on the course number and grading option.

Title: Are there any scholarships available?
Body:
Are there any scholarships available?

Yes. These are types types of scholarships available:

1.  Empowerment and Opportunity Fund (EOF) and GROW Scholarships - information available here.

2. HFA Scholarships - A limited number of HFA Scholarships are available for students and are awarded subject to availability of funds. Contact us at help@professional.ucsb.edu for more information.

Title: Are Professional and Continuing Education Credits Transferable?
Body:
Are Professional and Continuing Education Credits Transferable?

Professional and continuing education credits can be transferable; however, as with any credit, you are urged to verify acceptability of the credit through consultation with your own college program advisor. (Note: Petitions must be filed with the appropriate UCSB college or school prior to enrollment.) Professional and continuing education credit is based on the quarter system. One quarter unit equals two-thirds of a semester unit.

Title: Are all facilities and activities on campus available to UCSB International Programs students?
Body:
Are all facilities and activities on campus available to UCSB International Programs students?

Please be aware that as a UCSB International Programs student, you do NOT have access to the following:

  • GOLD, the Student Registration Services
  • A Perm Number
  • Campus Learning Assistance Services (CLAS)
  • "Late night" access to the UCSB Library and computer laboratories
  • Events and festivals sponsored by UCSB Associated Students (funded by UCSB undergraduate student fees), including:
    • The Halloween Concert
    • Extravaganza

Note: All UCSB Current/Public Events, however, are available to you (for free or a nominal fee).

Title: Recording of Professional Courses
Body:
Recording of Professional Courses

University policy prohibits audio or visual recording of class sessions unless a written request is approved by the Dean of Professional and Continuing Education.

Title: Classroom Behavior and Expectations
Body:
Classroom Behavior and Expectations

In a university setting, you will be treated and respected as an adult. Your attitude and behavior contributes to a successful and positive course experience. It is therefore important for each student to take an active role in her/his learning. It may be difficult or uncomfortable for you to actively participate in class discussions and small group activities at first. However, it is one of the most important skills to learn at the university. It is important to note that you get out of a course what you put into it. Students are encouraged to share academic needs, concerns, fears, challenges, and victories with their instructor and/or classmates. A course is much more rewarding if you fully participate. Each instructor takes her/his job seriously and is committed to helping all students to be successful. You are expected to adhere to the following standards of classroom performance and behavior to maximize learning.

Basic Ground Rules
Students are encouraged to:

  • Value differences as strengths
  • Participate in the learning process, classroom activities, and discussions
  • Be thoughtful, timely, and courteous when expressing a different point of view
  • Allow one person to speak at a time
  • Laugh with each other‚Äînot at each other
  • Maintain confidentiality if requested
  • Have consideration for opinions other than your own
  • Avoid monopolizing class time‚Äîeveryone participates
  • Keep an open mind‚Äîseek to understand others' viewpoints
  • Enjoy the course!

Homework Assignments, Projects, and Tests (In-class and Out-of-class)
Homework assignments, projects, and tests are listed in the class syllabus. Typically, homework counts as part of your grade. Instructors notify students in advance of any changes in assignments.

Assignments must adhere to the following:

  • Completed prior to each class for the class session they are assigned
  • Neat, easy-to-read, and well organized
  • Submitted by the due date
  • Completed independently unless otherwise indicated by the instructor

Note: Materials (written or otherwise) submitted to fulfill academic requirements must represent your own efforts unless otherwise permitted by the instructor. When you are allowed/encouraged to discuss and collaborate on assignments, the final product must be in you own words. The burden is always on the writer to make sure that his/her writing is clear to the reader.

Assignments, tests, midterms, and finals cannot be made up without prior arrangement with the instructor.

Attendance and Participation
You must do the following:

  • Attend all class sessions (required for all courses)
  • Arrive to class on time
  • Be prepared with all materials needed for class
  • Confirm role-call in person (do not confirm for a person that is not present)
  • Participate fully, which means contributing thoughts, ideas, and questions that are relevant to the course
  • Raise your hand to ask a question

During class, you are not allowed to use electronics for uses other than taking notes for a lecture or presentation or for dictionary purposes. 

You should also refrain from the following:

  • Socializing
  • Holding non-course related conversations with other students
  • Repeatedly speaking one's native language during class
  • Passing notes
  • Showing disrespect or lack of courtesy toward another individual
  • Denying other students an equal opportunity to participate in class
  • Refusing to cooperate with teachers and other students
  • Sleeping in class or work on other assignments during class instruction

Academic Integrity
The following information is an excerpt from Academic Integrity at UCSB: A Student's Guide

All members of the academic community share responsibility for the academic integrity of the UCSB community. Academic dishonesty is an assault upon the basic integrity and meaning of a university. Cheating, plagiarism, and collusion in dishonest activities are serious acts that erode the university's educational and research roles and cheapen the learning experience as well as the value of your degree.

It is expected that you will support the ideal of academic integrity and that you will be responsible for the integrity of your work. Materials (written or otherwise) submitted to fulfill academic requirements must represent your own efforts unless otherwise permitted by an instructor. It is also your responsibility to know the campus rules regarding academic misconduct. Remember that ignorance of these rules is no excuse.

Common Types of Academic Dishonesty
Cheating: Cheating is the unauthorized use of information or study guides in any academic exercise unless otherwise permitted by the instructor. Cheating includes the following:

  • Copying from others during an examination
  • Sharing answers for a take-home examination
  • Using illegal notes during an examination
  • Taking an examination for another student
  • Asking or allowing another student to take an examination for you
  • Tampering with an examination after it has been corrected, then returning it for more credit than deserved
  • Submitting substantial portions of the same academic work for credit in more than one course, without consulting with the second instructor (and the first instructor if the courses are concurrent at UCSB)
  • Preparing answers or writing notes in a blue book before an examination
  • Allowing others to do the research and writing of an assigned paper (for example, using the services of a commercial term paper company)
  • Sending messages to another student during an examination 

Plagiarism/Internet Plagiarism: Plagiarism is academic theft. It is the use of another's idea or words without proper attribution or credit. An author's work is his/her property and should be respected by documentation. Plagiarism from the Internet is no different from traditional plagiarism, and is in fact often far easier to catch with the use of technology available to instructors and administrators. It is a good idea to ask each instructor how they require sources to be noted and what constitutes "common knowledge" in their field to avoid possible problems.

Credit must be given for the following:

  • For every direct quotation
  • When a work is paraphrased or summarized in whole or in part in your own words
  • For information that is not common knowledge (it appears in several sources about the subject)

UCSB History Professor Sears McGee advises: "Generally, if a student writes while looking at a source or while looking at notes taken from a source, a footnote should be given."

Each professor should announce his/her specific requirements to guide students in their research. If you do not receive such guidance from your professors, you should request it specifically to ensure that you are not violating any rules.

Collusion
If you help another student to perform any of the above acts you are subject to campus discipline for academic dishonesty. There is no distinction between those who cheat and plagiarize and those who willingly allow it to occur.

Responsibilities
All citizens of the academic community have a responsibility to ensure that scholastic honesty and integrity are safeguarded and maintained. Cheating and plagiarism are unfair, demoralizing, and demeaning to all of us. Students are expected to:

  • Refrain from cheating and plagiarism
  • Refuse to aid or abet any form of academic dishonesty
  • Notify professors during an examination (or immediately after) about any observed incident of cheating

Title: BCBA/BCaBA Courses for International Students*: Options for Enrollment
Body:
BCBA/BCaBA Courses for International Students*: Options for Enrollment

*This program is only eligible for US, Canadian, UK, and Australian residents. If you reside in another country, please consider our QBA program.

The coursework requirement to become a board certified behavior analyst (BCBA) with UCSB Professional and Continuing Education is offered fully online. Courses can be taken from your home country, or while on-campus (with department approval.) Please find the options below to see which one suits your situation best:


#1) Enroll in BCBA/BCaBA courses from home country
Study with us from afar! BCBA/BCaBA courses are offered fully online, so you can participate like any other student from around the world. Courses will use the UCSB online learning platform, Guachospace, to structure the curriculum and allow for posting of assignments, discussion forums and exams. When you finish the certificate, we will mail it to you!

Course fees are the same as any domestic/community pricing.

#2) Enroll in BCBA/BCaBA courses while on campus
As a full-time international student on a F-1 student visa, you are eligible to take one online course per quarter. So, if you are enrolled in the University Immersion Program or the International Certificate Program, you can organize your schedule to allow for 1 BCBA/BCaBA online course (4 units) to contribute to your 12 required units.

Course fees will be included in your program flat fee tuition.

Title: For UCSB Students what are the estimated costs for the Medical Humanities Certificate Program?
Body:
For UCSB Students what are the estimated costs for the Medical Humanities Certificate Program?

$1,590 for the two PaCE courses but there's currently a 50% discount for current and former UCSB students. In addition, a $50 discount is given to students who pre-enroll before the early bird date listed on each designated course. If you enroll online, be sure to click on the "Early Bird Discount" button. To qualify, enrollment must be paid in full by the early bird fee deadline. 

In addition, a limited number of HFA Scholarships are available for students and are awarded subject to availability of funds. In combination with the PaCE Discount above, scholarship recipients will not pay any tuition for 2020-21 PaCE courses! To apply for the HFA Scholarship, please submit your application HERE.

Title: When and How to Enroll in my diploma courses?
Body:
When and How to Enroll in my diploma courses?

You can enroll into courses as soon as they are published for each quarter (approximately 8 to 10 weeks before the quarter starts).

Since you will pay a flat tuition fee per quarter, you will not have to pay to enroll in individual courses. To enroll in certificate courses, you have a few options:

Pre-arrival
- Coupon Code:
Enter 'INT2022' at checkout of each course to be enrolled at no cost. Help video here.

Post-arrival
- Orientation:
Enroll in courses with academic advisor 

Note: You must enroll in courses prior to the first class meeting.

Title: Can SIP courses be taken for pass/fail grades?
Body:
Can SIP courses be taken for pass/fail grades?

Courses in this program can only be taken for letter grades.  The pass/fail option is not available.

Title: How can I learn more about VMock?
Body:
How can I learn more about VMock?

Once you are logged into VMock, you can click the Take a Tour button to help you get oriented with the platform.

Title: Textbook information
Body:
Textbook information

Open University textbooks and course materials are not included in Open University fees. Textbook information can be found on each course link here (to find the course you are interested in, click on "Course Title," and then click on "Textbook Information.") 

Textbooks may be purchased at the UCSB Campus Bookstore; however, supplementary required materials will be announced in class or listed on the course syllabus.

NOTE: It is recommended that you purchase textbooks once you have confirmed enrollment in the course, not before.

Title: ABA eligibility to enroll in Research Practicum I and Research Practicum II
Body:
ABA eligibility to enroll in Research Practicum I and Research Practicum II

Hello ,

Thank you for your email and interest in the Applied Behavior Analysis program offered through UCSB Extension. Enrollment for this program is revolving. You may enter the program in any quarter. The matrix on the certificate page indicates which course is offered for each academic quarter.

To be eligible to enroll in Research Practicum I and Research Practicum II, you must concurrently be completing your practicum hours. These courses are research courses, which require reading and engaging with online lectures, and completing projects that require application of your knowledge and understanding with the actual work you are completing in the practicum.

Please let us know if you have additional questions.

Title: What is the process for obtaining my BCBA/BCaBA through UCSB's PaCE programs?
Body:
What is the process for obtaining my BCBA/BCaBA through UCSB's PaCE programs?

BCBA (Board Certified Behavior Analyst)

  • UCSB PaCE offers ABAI approved 5th Edition Verified Course Sequence to those planning on becoming a BCBA. Under the 5th Edition task list, students will need a Master's degree in any field/discipline. Students will complete 315 coursework hours (total of 7 classes) and accrue 2000 supervised fieldwork hours. For more information regarding BACB's requirements, click here. 

BCaBA (Board Certified Assistant Behavior Analyst)

  • Assistants of BCBAs can apply for this type of certificate. Assistants perform helpful tasks and are able to supervise RBTs. BCaBAs must have their undergraduate degree, must have completed at least 225 coursework hours, accrue 1300 supervised fieldwork hours, and then pass the exam administered by BACB. For more information regarding BACB's requirements, click here.

Title: What student services are included in the flat tuition fee?
Body:
What student services are included in the flat tuition fee?

By paying the Student Services Fee, international students are given:

  • Health Insurance Coverage

  • Unlimited use of local bus transportation (SBMTD)

  • Recreation Center membership

  • Library access

  • Discounts to select campus events

  • Occasional free entrance to athletic events

  • Access to Office of International Students and Scholars events and programs

  • Immigration Advising and official US government immigration documentation

Title: Professional Sequence Awards
Body:
Professional Sequence Awards

Professional Sequence Awards are a series of credit and/or noncredit courses that total 90 or more hours of instruction. They offer concentrated, accelerated study of an individual subject or cluster of related subjects. Earning a Professional Sequence Award enables you to update and upgrade specific skill areas quickly and will provide evidence to employers of recent, specialized study. Courses carry professional credit or Continuing Education Units (CEUs), and most qualify for employer-paid assistance or tuition reimbursement. Professional Sequence Awards are generally earned within three quarters or less. Formal application to the program is required.

Title: Withdrawal from Professional Credit Courses X300 to X499
Body:
Withdrawal from Professional Credit Courses X300 to X499

If you wish to withdraw from a professional credit course, you may do so until the last class session without a course grade penalty, provided you notify Student Services by using our help request form.  You should also notify the instructor of the course. An "NC" (No Credit) grade will be recorded in this case. This grade carries no penalty; however you must repeat and pass the course in order to apply it toward a Certificate Program.

Title: Does the Child Life program offer support for securing an internship/practicum?
Body:
Does the Child Life program offer support for securing an internship/practicum?

UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) does not offer internship opportunities and we do not have contractual affiliation agreements with local hospitals. Therefore, our program is covered unaffiliated. 

Please find a List of Hospitals accepting unaffiliated Interns.
