Title: Will I be able to enroll in the courses I want to take?
Body:
Will I be able to enroll in the courses I want to take?

Enrollment in courses is limited and space is not guaranteed. You must meet all prerequisites listed on the course in order to enroll. If you are unable to enroll in your first-choice courses, you must be prepared with a list of back-up course choices. The process for enrolling in courses is specific to the type of courses you wish to enroll in.

At the beginning of each quarter before instruction begins, UCSB International Programs conducts academic advising sessions. During your session, you will be advised about the probability of available spaces in UCSB Regular Session courses.

Note: Students enrolled in degree programs at UCSB have priority enrollment in all UCSB regular session courses.

Title: If you are a UCSB matriculated student and you are enrolling in a PaCE course, please follow the steps below to access your PaCE course in Canvas
Body:
If you are a UCSB matriculated student and you are enrolling in a PaCE course, please follow the steps below to access your PaCE course in Canvas

Because you are a UCSB matriculated student, you have likely used Canvas before. However UCSB PaCE courses require a separate Canvas account.

Please make sure that your ucsb.edu email address is your preferred email address in your PaCE Student Profile before you enroll in a PaCE course.

Within an hour of enrolling in a PaCE course but no sooner than 60 days before the beginning of the course, you will receive an email similar to the one below from UCSB Canvas to the preferred email address in your PaCE student profile with instructions on how to complete your Canvas registration and access your online course.  Do not disregard that email.

  • Example of the email you will receive. Please follow the instructions provided in that email.

  • Once you click on the link, you will be asked to combine your new Canvas account with your existing UCSB Canvas (see below).

  • Please confirm that you are the same person listed on that email and you will be directed to Canvas where you will see both your UCSB academic courses and your PaCE courses.
  • If your ucsb.edu email address has not been set up as your preferred email address in your PaCE Student Profile before enrolling in a PaCE course, you will have two separate Canvas accounts.
  • If you didn't follow the instructions above and you didn't combine your two Canvas accounts, then you will have two separate Canvas accounts. You will need to access your PaCE courses in Canvas following these instructions instead.

If you have any questions about the above instructions, please feel free to email us at help@professional.ucsb.edu or call us at 805-893-4200 and we will be happy to assist you. We are available Monday through Friday, from 9am to 5pm PST. We are closed on weekends and major Federal Holidays.

Title: Sexual Harassment
Body:
Sexual Harassment

Federal and state laws, as well as University of California Systemwide and Santa Barbara campus policies, prohibit sexual harassment in an educational setting. Grievance procedures designed specifically for this form of discrimination apply to students in regular UCSB courses, in Open University courses, and in professional and continuing education courses. UCSB procedures for sexual harassment complaints are available online. Further information and assistance for sexual harassment can be obtained from the following:

UCSB Sexual Harassment Officer
Office of Equal Opportunity and Sexual Harassment/Title IX Compliance
University of California
3217 A Phelps Hall
(805) 893-2546

Title: QBA/QASP-S Courses for international students: Options for Enrollment
Body:
QBA/QASP-S Courses for international students: Options for Enrollment

The coursework requirement to become a qualified behavior analyst (QBA) with UCSB Professional and Continuing Education is offered fully online. Courses can be taken from your home country, or while on-campus (with department approval.) Please find the options below to see which one suits your situation best:

#1) Enroll in QBA/QASP-S courses from your home country:

Study with us from afar! QBA/QASP-S courses are offered fully online, so you can participate like any other student from around the world. Courses will use the UCSB online learning platform, Guachospace, to structure the curriculum and allow for posting of assignments, discussion forums and exams. When you finish the certificate, we will mail it to you!

Course fees are the same as any domestic/community pricing.

#2) Enroll in QBA/QASP-S courses while on campus

As a full-time international student on a F-1 student visa, you are eligible to take one online course per quarter. So, if you are enrolled in the University Immersion Program or the International Certificate Program, you can organize your schedule to allow for 1 QBA/QASP-S online course (4 units) to contribute to your 12 required units.

Course fees will be included in your program flat fee tuition.

Title: Open University Dropping Courses/Withdrawal Procedures
Body:
Open University Dropping Courses/Withdrawal Procedures

Prior to the Deadline

You are responsible to notify us in writing to drop an Open University course in which you are enrolled. To formally drop a course, please submit a written drop request using our help request form.

Requests to drop must be received by our Customer Success Office no later than 4 p.m. on the deadline date which you can find here. Courses dropped prior to this deadline will not appear on your permanent transcript records.

Students who file drop requests by the drop deadline are eligible for a full refund of their course fees minus a $40 Administrative Fee per course.

After the Deadline

In order to request permission to drop a course after the drop deadline, you must submit the Petition for Late or Retroactive Drop form to our Customer Success Team, along with written documentation of extenuating circumstances and the required fee. Your instructor must endorse dropping the course after the deadline. Please submit your completed Petition here.

Exceptions to the published drop deadline are granted only in very unusual and compelling circumstances. Permission to drop after the deadline can only be granted by the Division of Professional and Continuing Education. A Withdrawal (W) grade will be assigned when you receive permission to drop a course after the drop deadline. Failure to formally withdraw from a course you do not complete will result in the recording of an F or NP grade.

No refund of fees are issued after the drop deadline.

Title: Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Business Administration and Management
Body:
Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Business Administration and Management

A certificate is awarded upon completion of the 6-7 required courses totaling 22 units (or 198 hours of instruction), listed in the Program Schedule each with a letter grade of "C" / "Pass" or better. A total of 8 units must come from courses in the same specialization area.  All requirements must be completed within five (5) years after the student enrolls in their first course. Students not pursuing a certificate are welcome to take as many individual courses as they wish.

There are no prerequisites for courses in this certificate nor is a bachelor's degree required.

To become an official candidate in the program, students need only register in one of the courses in the approved curriculum.

Request for Certificate Release

Application Fee $95.00

If all the Certificate requirements have been met, after your request is processed, you will receive an email notification from Parchment with a digital copy of your Certificate. A printed copy will be mailed via regular US Postal Service to the mailing address provided in your PaCE Student Profile 8-10 business days after receipt of the digital copy.

The $95 Certificate Release Fee is non-refundable. This Fee is required in order to receive a copy of your Certificate.

Click here to request your Certificate Release.

Title: Class Auditing
Body:
Class Auditing

As a student of the Division of Professional and Continuing Education, you will not be allowed to audit or visit professional courses. Payment is due at the time of enrollment. Access to a classroom is available 15 minutes before the class is scheduled to begin.

Open University Courses

During the regular academic year, you may audit a regular session UCSB course (sit in unofficially) with the permission of the instructor. Auditors are not expected to complete assignments, take examinations, or participate in classroom discussion. No record of the audited class will appear on your quarter schedule or UCSB transcript. You will not be permitted to earn credit by examination in courses that you have audited.

Title: How do I transfer from another school to UCSB International Programs?
Body:
How do I transfer from another school to UCSB International Programs?

If you are studying on an F-1 visa at another U.S. school and you wish to apply to one of our UCSB International Programs, you will first need to apply and be accepted.

Once you are accepted to UCSB International Programs and pay your program tuition fees, you will fill out our Transfer In Form and submit it to the Immigration Advisor. We will use this information to coordinate the transfer of your I-20 in the SEVIS database to UCSB International Programs. Your former school may ask for a copy of your letter of acceptance prior to releasing your I-20.

Note that you must begin your studies at UCSB International Programs during the next available quarter, which can be no later than five months from the program end date at your previous school.

Title: International agents and liability insurance
Body:
International agents and liability insurance

International agencies and organizations with no US-based offices are not required to provide the liability insurance coverage outlined in the professional services agreement.

The provision, however, will remain in the agreement because it is used for all suppliers we do business with. So, if it does not apply to you, kindly ignore the section, and we will not ask for proof of coverage.

If you have any questions about the liability insurance provision for US-based companies, and if it applies to your agency, please contact us at help@professional.ucsb.edu

Body:
Open University Transcripts

Transcript records for Open University course work are not automatically sent to UCSB's Registrar and/or Office of Admissions.

To request a PaCE Official transcript, please follow the instructions in How to order a Transcript.

When filling out your transcript request, please use one of these options:

Santa Barbara, CA 93106-2070

Title: What is the Young Scholars Program?
Body:
What is the Young Scholars Program ?

The Young Scholar Program is coordinated through UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) to offer local high-achieving, pre-college students  an opportunity to begin university-level studies at UCSB while still in high school. Enrollment for Young Scholars Program is for Fall, Winter, and Spring quarters. Summer quarter enrollment occurs through Summer Sessions

Title: Notice of Availability of the UCSB Annual Security Report
Body:
Notice of Availability of the UCSB Annual Security Report

The University is committed to providing a safe and secure campus environment for our students, faculty, staff, and visitors. In accordance with the "Jeanne Clery Disclosure of Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act" (Clery Act), UCSB publishes an Annual Security Report to provide information regarding campus safety and security policies, crime statistics, and resources to current and prospective students and employees. This report includes statistics for the previous three years concerning crimes reported to Campus Security Authorities that occurred on campus, in certain off-campus buildings or property, and on public property adjacent to and accessible from campus. To access the Annual Security Report, visit www.police.ucsb.edu/asr. A copy of this report may also be requested by contacting the UCSB Police Department (call 805-893-3446 or visit 574 Public Safety Bldg., Santa Barbara, CA 93106 during business hours). To learn more about the Clery Act, please visit www.police.ucsb.edu/clery-act.

Title: How Do I Order a Certificate?
Body:
How Do I Order a Certificate?

Starting in Winter 2021, we are offering both electronic and printed Certificates via Parchment, our online credential service provider.

Please check your Program page for detailed information and request procedures. In most Programs, you will find "3 Easy Steps to Request Certificate" at the bottom of the page after Pricing. Please follow those easy steps to order your Certificate.

If your Program does not have the "3 Easy Steps to Request Certificate" at the bottom of the page, your Certificate is included in your initial Certificate Application Fee. In this case, when all the Certificate requirements have been met and final grades are posted, you will receive an email notification from Parchment with a digital copy of your Certificate. A printed copy will be mailed via regular US Postal Service to the mailing address provided in your PaCE Student Profile 8-10 business days after receipt of the digital copy.

EXCEPTION: Students who successfully complete XLRN 815.EMT - Emergency Medical Technician will receive an electronic and a printed Certificate via Parchment. No Certificate Request is required for this specific Certificate. It will be issued once the final grade is posted in the PaCE Student Profile.

Duplicate Certificates

If you need to order a Duplicate Certificate, you can submit a Duplicate Certificate Request on the Student Portal under "Special Requests". There is a $35 Fee per request.

Duplicate certificates will be released via Parchment, our online credential service provider.

The certificate will be available in both digital and printed format. At checkout, please review your PaCE Student Profile information and make sure that your email address, street address, and phone number are current.

A digital copy will be sent to your email address on file. A printed copy will be mailed via regular US Postal Service to the mailing address provided in your Profile 8-10 business days after receipt of the digital copy.

Title: Will the certificate be noted somewhere on my degree?
Body:
Will the certificate be noted somewhere on my degree?

No, student records and grades for professional courses taken through UCSB PaCE are separate from the records for UCSB's academic courses and degree programs.  

Upon completion of the Strategic Investments Program, UCSB PaCE will award a certificate to document the accomplishment.  You can find detailed instructions on how to order an official transcript from UCSB PaCE here.

Please note that certificates will only be issued to students that have submitted an application and subsequently admitted to the program.

Title: Do I need to file tax forms as an international student?
Body:
Do I need to file tax forms as an international student?

Per UCSB OISS's website: 

April 15 is "Tax Day" in the U.S. 

If you earned an income from any source between January 1 and December 31 of any given year, you must file both Federal and State income tax returns.

If you did not earn an income, you are still required to file Form 8843. This short form is not an income tax return but an informational statement required by the U.S. government. More information can be found on page 3-4 of the form.

Unfortunately, OISS nor PaCE is not able to assist with tax advice or filing in any way.

Scholars and students are fully responsible for filing their own taxes. You can find resources to help with this at the link to OISS's website above.

Title: Private Student Loan Information
Body:
Private Student Loan Information

Financing Your Education through Private Student Loans

With careful use, private loans can help to bridge the gap between the cost of UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) programs/courses and your ability to pay for them.

Students have the right and the ability to select the private loan lender of their choice. We encourage you to review the lender terms and conditions and carefully consider the benefits and repayment information before choosing a lender. Please note that UCSB PaCE programs and courses are not eligible for federally sponsored (Title IV) financial assistance.

The University of California Office of the President has put together a list of recommended lenders. You are not required to use any of the lenders on the list, but are simply provided for your convenience. If you have specific questions related to your credit history, the contact information for alternative loan lenders is available on the Student Loan Application Portal on the Private Lenders website.

To secure your loan for UCSB PaCE Programs/Courses, you must do the following:

  1. In order to receive loan proceeds, you must apply to the lender directly.
  2. Your student loan must be approved by the bank and certified by UCSB Professional and Continuing Education at least four weeks prior to your first class meeting.
  3. Once your loan has been approved by the lender, in order for your loan to be certified, please contact Student Services with your proposed courses. We will need to know which course/s you intend to complete for each quarter and if you need textbooks funds for each quarter. PaCE only certifies loans for the Program total cost. Living expenses or other types of personal expenses cannot be certified by PaCE.
  4. Loans are certified each term (1 year) for a maximum of the total amount of course fees, $35 for the Loan Certification Fee (per quarter), $150 (or $95 or $45 depending on the Program) for the Certificate of Candidacy/Release Fee, and $150 towards textbooks if needed (per quarter).

Per HEOA guidelines, our office adheres to the University of California Student Loan Code of Conduct.

It is recommended that you begin the loan application process early as UCSB PaCE does not enroll students in courses until payment is received, and applying for a loan does not reserve a space in the course.

Student Loan Deferment

Students enrolled in courses through UCSB PaCE, who have prior federal student loans, are not eligible for loan deferments. Federal loan deferments are approved only when a "student is enrolled in a program leading to a degree or certificate at an eligible institution (i.e. one that is eligible for federal loans)." Programs offered through UCSB PaCE are not eligible for federal loans. Student services staff can verify course/program enrollment, but cannot complete the school section of forms related to loan deferment of FFELP (Federal Family Education Loan Program), Federal Direct (William D. Ford Federal Direct), Stafford, Perkins, and PLUS loans.

Title: Can I Enroll in a UCSB Undergraduate Course?
Body:
Can I Enroll in a UCSB Undergraduate Course?

If you meet all requirements, you may enroll in UCSB regular session courses held on campus through the Open University Program. This program lets you pay for courses on a per-unit basis as well as earn transferable units‚Äîall without being formally admitted to UCSB.

Title: What are the restrictions on an F-1 Visa?
Body:
What are the restrictions on an F-1 Visa?

Employment is considered work performed in exchange for compensation. Compensation can include money, room and board, or other significant benefits. Before you accept any kind of employment, be sure it is allowed according to F-1 regulations.

As an F-1 visa holder, you are allowed to engage in on-campus employment. The following are some important F-1 employment guidelines to remember:

  • You can work up to 20 hours per week if you are a full-time student.
  • You can work up to 40 hours per week if you are working during a vacation quarter. You are eligible for a vacation quarter after three consecutive quarters of full-time study.

It is important that you know and understand the regulations when seeking employment as an F-1 student. Please consult with a member of the Student Services team with any questions related to F-1 status and employment.

Title: Do I get a U-Mail account?
Body:
Do I get a U-Mail account?

Yes, though it may take up to five working days to access your U-Mail account.

Title: What constitutes an unacceptable drug test?
Body:
What constitutes an unacceptable drug test?

Any positive result of a 10-panel drug test will cause a student to be disqualified from the course. This includes those with medical marijuana card use.

If a student tests positive for marijuana or any other tested drugs, they will not be allowed into a medical facility which will make them ineligible for later certification. A student must submit to drug testing.

If an individual thinks they might show a positive result, do not take the course. Specifics of a 10-panel drug test can be found online.

Title: Local Laws and County Ordinances
Body:
Local Laws and County Ordinances

In California, no one under the age of 21 is allowed to consume or possess alcohol. The following information is an excerpt from the UCSB Alcohol and Drug Program.

Campus Police and the Isla Vista Foot Patrol strictly enforce the law. UCSB students should be familiar with local and state laws and county ordinances that apply on campus and in the community of Isla Vista. A list of these laws and ordinances as well as penalties and fines can be found on the Santa Barbara Sheriff's Office/Isla Vista Foot Patrol page. The following is a partial list of illegal activities that carry stiff fines and/or suspension of a driver's license (some violations will result in arrest and booking into jail):

    • Minor in possession of alcohol or furnishing alcohol to a minor
    • Driving/biking under the influence and public intoxication
    • Display of an open container of alcohol; public consumption of alcohol
    • Possession of alcohol in Isla Vista parks
    • Possession of marijuana; possession of drug paraphernalia
    • Possession of false identification
    • Urinating in public
    • Nighttime noise violation (amplified noise Sunday-Thursday after 10 p.m.; Friday/Saturday after 12 a.m.) or disturbing the peace

Title: How do I maintain an F-1 Visa status?
Body:
How do I maintain an F-1 Visa status?

As an F-1 student it is your responsibility to know and understand what it means to maintain your status. Failure to adhere to the requirements will result in the termination of your F-1 visa. Students with a terminated F-1 visa must discontinue their studies immediately and arrange to leave the U.S. No refunds of program fees, student services, or course fees will be given in the event of F-1 termination status.

In order to maintain your F-1 student visa status, you must enroll in and complete a full course of study. This means you must enroll in courses for credit, you must attend each class, and you must take the minimum quarterly course load of the following:

  • 12 units undergraduate (course numbers X1-X199, XSB1-XSB199) or
  • 12 units professional-level (course numbers X300-X499) or
  • 8 units graduate (course numbers XSB200-XSB299) or
  • 12 units in a combination of undergraduate/graduate/professional-level courses

Summer-Six Weeks

  • 8 units undergraduate (course numbers X1-X199, XSB1-XSB199) or
  • 6 units graduate (course numbers XSB200-XSB299) or
  • ‚Äã8 units in a combination of undergraduate/graduate/professional-level courses

Please note that online or distance learning classes are limited to three credits per session toward a full course of study for an F-1 student during each quarter. An online, or distance learning, course for the purpose of international student regulations means a course that is primarily offered through technology and does not require the student's physical attendance for classes, examinations or other purposes integral to completion of the class.

You are expected to attend your classes and to fully participate in them. If you must miss a class due to illness, travel, or any other reason, it is your responsibility to contact the instructor as soon as possible and inquire about the possibility of making up any missed coursework. Students who miss classes and do not complete the missed assignments do not fulfill the "full-time" study requirements of the F-1 student visa.

You will be in violation of your F-1 status if you fail to do the following:

  • Enroll in a full load of courses. 
  • Apply for a Reduced Course Load (RCL) authorization by published deadlines.
  • Get prior authorization for dropping below a full course of study.

UC Santa Barbara Professional and Continuing Education is required to report your failure to maintain your status to SEVIS within 21 days.

If you have difficulty finding a full course of study, please contact the University Immersion Program Director for assistance at isp@extension.ucsb.edu.

Title: Can I register for ECON X499.4 or SIP electives while I'm completing their respective course prerequisites?
Body:
Can I register for ECON X499.4 or SIP electives while I'm completing their respective course prerequisites?

Yes.  However, the self enrollment system does not allow students to bypass the prerequisites while concurrently enrolled. 

 

Students may contact PaCE Support at 805-893-4200 to enroll over the phone or in person at 2160 Kerr Hall (Office Hours: Monday - Friday, 9AM - 5PM PST).

Title: Open University Scholarships FAQ
Body:
Open University Scholarships FAQ

Who?

Scholarships are reserved to all residents of Santa Barbara, San Luis Obispo, Ventura and Kern counties who are interested in taking UCSB courses via Open University, regardless of their previous UCSB affiliation.

Current UCSB students are not eligible for these scholarships. Please refer to this article for instructions on how to enroll in Open University Program. 

UCSB students who have been dismissed are not eligible for these scholarships. Please find more information on our Open University Program here.

When?

Open University Scholarships are available for Fall, Winter and Spring Quarters. Apply anytime up to 4 weeks before the start of the quarter according to the UCSB academic calendar when you intend to take your class. 

Fall 2023 Quarter Scholarships
Deadline: September 8, 2023.
Response by September 18, 2023

Only the selected Awardees will be notified. If you do not receive a notification, you were not selected

Winter 2024 Quarter Scholarships

To be determined

Spring 2024 Quarter Scholarships

To be determined

How much?

Scholarships cover 100% of the Open University tuition costs for one course. The $25 non-refundable quarterly enrollment fee, textbooks, and additional lab fees are not covered. They are payable by the student.

Enrollment is dependent on space availability. Please note that enrollment approval is ultimately at the Academic Department's discretion. If you are unable to enroll in the course of your choice during the quarter in question, please email help@professional.ucsb.edu for deferment options.

How do I apply for this Scholarship? 

To apply please fill out this form.  Only the selected Awardees will be notified.

Regardless of your Scholarship status, you will still be eligible to take UCSB courses through Open University and earn credits towards your degree completion.

What do I need to know about the courses taken via Open University?

Find additional information here

Title: Academic Calendar
Body:
Academic Calendar

Students enrolled through the Division of Professional and Continuing Education adhere to the regular UCSB Academic Calendar.

If you are an international student, the International Student Programs: Dates page will detail more information about application deadlines and other important quarter dates. 

If you are a student in the Open University Program, the Calendar, Fees, and Major Deadlines page will tell you more about important dates for enrollment, drop dates, and other important quarter dates.

Title: Which Visa do I need?
Body:
Which Visa do I need?

Before you can apply for your F-1 student visa, you must first apply and be accepted into our UCSB Professional and Continuing Education International Student Program.

Once you're accepted, you will be required to pay the SEVIS I-901 fee in order to be enrolled in the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System (SEVIS). Then, we will provide you with a Form I-20. You'll need to present this form to the consular officer when you attend your F-1 visa interview. If your spouse and/or children plan to reside in the U.S. with you while you study, they will be required to have individual Form I-20s, but they will not need to be enrolled in the SEVIS.

Title: Course Textbook and Materials
Body:
Course Textbook and Materials

Course Textbooks

Order textbooks from the bookseller of your choice, including online sellers specializing in textbook sales and rentals. However, you should check to make sure you are ordering textbooks with the correct ISBN and edition. The Division of Professional and Continuing Education will not reimburse you for course materials if you order the wrong edition or if a course section is cancelled or rescheduled. Check for updated course textbook information in the course search.

Note: Textbook costs are not included in tuition fees unless noted on our website. If the course fee indicates that it includes the cost of a textbook, the books will be distributed at the first class session.

Textbooks for professional and continuing education courses are not available through the UCSB campus bookstore.

For further information about textbooks for professional and continuing education courses, contact us here.

Additional Course Materials

Specific courses may include additional course materials charges. This information is included in the section notes for the course. Fees for course materials are nonrefundable.

Title: Invoicing UCSB PaCE
Body:
Invoicing UCSB PaCE

Commission Payment Terms

  • Submit one invoice per quarter. If you have multiple students enrolling in the same International Student Program, attach a list to the invoice with the complete name and date of birth (mm/dd/yyyy) for each student enrolled in the program.

  • Before a commission payment is processed, the following must be on file at UCSB Professional and Continuing Education:
    • Current Representative/Agent Application;
    • Payment of the ISP Program Application fees for all students attending through Organization/Agency;
    • Current signed Professional Services Agreement with UCSB Processional and Continuing Education. Professional Services Agreement must be finalized prior to receipt of student application.

Commission Payments

  • Representative/Agent Commission invoice is required for payment
  • Payment will only be processed for current programs and quarters only. Invoices for future programs or quarters will not be paid
  • Payments will be made no earlier than 30 days after the drop deadlines for the quarter/program.
  • Terms may vary per agreement

Submit your Commission invoice using Professional and Continuing Education Invoice form.

Or, if you prefer your own invoice format, please make sure to include the following information:

  • Student Roster (Names and student IDs)
  • Quarter Enrolled
  • Commission amount (in accordance with Agent agreement we have with you)
  • Preferred form of payment (Check or Wire transfer)
  • Banking information if Wire transfer is requested:

    Payee Bank Account Number
    Bank Name
    Payee Name on Bank Account
    Payee Address Linked to Bank Account
    International Wire: Bank's SWIFT or BIC Code or
    U.S. Wire: Bank's ABA Fedwire Routing Number
    Bank Address
    Intermediary Bank Information, if required

Please be aware that a wire transfer fees will be deducted from the commission as follows:

  • U.S. Bank: $18.00
  • International Bank: $9.50"

Title: How do I apply and enroll in the Young Scholars Program ?
Body:
How do I apply and enroll in the Young Scholars Program ?

High school guidance counselors and/or principals should submit nominations of students seeking to enter the Young Scholars Program early the previous quarter.  For Spring quarter enrollment, for example, nominations should be made during the early weeks of the Winter quarter.  Please consult UCSB academic calendar to know the quarter dates. The following information should be submitted for each student nominated via email to the Young Scholars Program Coordinator. Be sure that each page includes the name of the student being nominated.

  • Nomination letter from guidance counselor or principal
  • Current high school transcript of the student
  • Copy of SAT, PSAT and/or AP scores

 The Letter of Nomination is the introduction of the student to the Young Scholars Program application Reviewing Committee. It  should include information such as:

  • A brief overview of the academic and social strengths of the student.
  • Identify outstanding course work and school participation, explain why you feel this student is outstanding.
  • Describe the maturity of the student. Is the student an independent thinker? Do you anticipate that the student will easily adjust to academics and life on campus?
  • List any academic or social concerns that you have about the student.

NOTE: Each page submitted should include the name of the student at the top of the page.

  • Next steps: The nomination packets (letters, transcripts, test scores) are reviewed by the Young Scholars Program Committee at PaCE.  The Committee will determine the eligibility of the student to attend the UCSB undergraduate courses.
  • If approved, the committee will confirm the students for the Young Scholars Program.
  • Guidance counselors and principals will be notified of the status of their submissions.

Once approved, the Young Scholars Program students will need to complete these steps to enroll in Open University.

Title: How Can I Forward My UCSB Email to My Personal Email Account
Body:
How Can I Forward My UCSB Email to My Personal Email Account

Forwarding Mail to Another Account

Google allows you to forward your e-mail to another account; you can also opt to leave a copy of the forwarded messages in your U-Mail Inbox. 
 
  1. Using Gmail, log into your U-Mail account that you want to forward from.
  2. At the top right, click the gear icon for Settings.
  3. Select Settings.
  4. Select the Forwarding and POP/IMAP tab.
  5. Click Add a forwarding address in the "Forwarding" section.
  6. Enter the email address you want to forward to ("receiving" account).
  7. For your security, Google will send a verification email to that address. Open the receiving account and find the confirmation message from the Gmail team. If you're having trouble finding it, check your Spam folder.
  8. Click the verification link in that email.
  9. Back in your U-Mail account, reload the page in your web browser - look for the reload icon Reload.
  10. On the same Forwarding and POP/IMAP page in Settings, check that Forward a copy of incoming mail is selected and your email address is in the first drop-down menu.
  11. In the second drop-down menu, choose what you want Google to do with your messages after they're forwarded, such as keep U-Mail's copy in the Inbox (recommended) or archive U-Mail's copy.
  12. Click Save Changes at the bottom of the page.

Title: Transfer Credit
Body:
Transfer Credit

Transfer UCSB Professional and Continuing Education Credit to Other Degrees or Institutions

Non-UC Degree

If you are seeking a degree from another university, we urge you to verify the acceptability of UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) credit through consultation with your own college program advisor prior to enrollment at UCSB PaCE.

UC Degree

If you are a matriculated student or an applicant for admission to the University of California, read the following guidelines:

UCSB PaCE Credit Courses (X1 to X199)

Upon petition to the respective UC Registrar's Office, credit earned in courses numbered X1 to X199 may be accepted in fulfillment of unit requirements on all UC campuses.

UCSB PaCE Credit Courses (X300 to X499)

Within the limitations prescribed by various colleges and schools, credit earned in courses numbered X300 to X499 (professional level credit courses in the field of education) may be accepted toward the B.A., B.S., or in post-graduate programs leading to recommendations for teacher credentials. However that determination is made exclusively by the receiving college/school/institution. We highly recommend that students discuss any transfer credit questions with their Department Advisor before enrolling in any PaCE courses. 

The usual procedures governing the evaluation of credits will determine transfer of these units for fulfilling subject requirements. Grade points earned are counted for admission purposes only, not for GPA.

UC Admissions

Participating in this educational program does not inherently provide preference for admission to the University of California. If you are interested in applying to UC, refer to the UC Admissions website or the admissions office of the UC campus you wish to attend for details about the admissions process.

Transfer Credit to UCSB Professional and Continuing Education from Other Degrees or Institutions

To transfer credit received at other colleges or universities to UCSB PaCE credit, please refer to the instructions on the individual certificate or course web pages.

Unit Values on Credit Courses

Credit courses for UCSB PaCE award units. These units are indicated in the certificate program matrices on the website and within the section information at the time of online enrollment. Units are an indicator of the length and depth of study. The minimum requirement for one quarter unit is nine hours of in-class time. UCSB PaCE operates on the quarter system. One quarter unit equals two-thirds of a semester unit.

Title: How Do I Access Online Forms?
Body:
How Do I Access Online Forms?

Useful forms are available in editable PDF versions on our website. You must install Adobe Reader 6.0 or higher on your computer to view the forms. Users may occasionally have difficulty printing or even opening complex forms online. If this occurs, please try saving the form to your computer. To do this, right click and then select "Save As" or "Save Link As" (or Control + Click for Mac) while hovering on the hyperlink to the desired form. Then, open and complete the form locally using Adobe Acrobat.

Title: What is a Form I-20?
Body:
What is a Form I-20?

A Form I-20 is the certificate of eligibility issued by a Designated School Official (DSO) at the school where you wish to enroll. This form will be included in your acceptance packet and has three pages. You will use this to apply for an F-1 student visa at a U.S. Embassy or consulate for the purpose of studying in the U.S. Your SEVIS ID number is printed on the first and second pages. The I-20 specifies a start and end date for your studies.

Note: Each dependent who accompanies you to the U.S. must have an individual F-2 Dependent Form I-20.

Title: Why should I complete a Professional Certificate Program?
Body:
Why should I complete a Professional Certificate Program?

Completion of a certificate program shows evidence to a current or future employer that you have recent professional-level training and development in a particular field. In some professions this evidence can lead to career advancement and/or a salary increase.

Title: VMock: Can I upload a document that is multiple pages?
Body:
VMock: Can I upload a document that is multiple pages?

You are able to upload a document that is multiple pages to VMock. However, because recruiting standards for most students' job search goals entail a one page resume, VMock will reflect this feedback through your resume score.

Title: If I've already completed ECON 1 and 2 at a community college will those count toward meeting the program prerequisites?
Body:
If I've already completed ECON 1 and 2 at a community college will those count toward meeting the program prerequisites?

Please contact the PaCE program manager to confirm eligibility.

Title: Child Life ED X370.7 Affiliated vs Independent Internships
Body:
Child Life ED X370.7 Affiliated vs Independent Internships

Hello,

Thank you for your email and interest in the Child Life Internship course.

As indicated on our website:
The University does not insure student interns under its insurance programs and does not enter into contractual agreements with the training site. Only verification of enrollment in ED X370.7 for course credit can be provided. A syllabus is available upon request.

To provide further clarification: There is a difference between being "affiliated" with a university for this internship and applying independently.  Further, "affiliated" can mean different things for different institutions. If "affiliation" means that the university is required to enter into an affiliation agreement or contract, then you will need to apply as "independent." If the affiliation requires you to be enrolled in a course and earn credit, per the Common Child Life Internship Application, then you can choose to be affiliated.

Since we first began offering child life courses (since 2013) we have found that there are quite a few hospitals throughout the country that accept independent students; but, not every hospital accepts independent applicants, so check each hospital's website or application packet for specifics. 

Finally, if you are actively working towards a degree, in addition to taking a child life course with us, ask your chair or academic advisor if your program is able to enter into contractual agreements with hospitals. If the answer is yes, then you can apply for practicums and internships as Affiliated.  

Hope this is helpful. Please let us know if you have additional questions.

 

Kind regards,

Title: Instructions for Importing UCSB Canvas Template
Body:
Instructions for Importing UCSB Canvas Template

Please note that you can find the below instructions on Canvas as well under "PaCE Instructor Resources".

Step 1: Log into your Canvas account and go to your course page. 

Step 2: On the right hand side there is a button that says, Import from Commons 



Step 3: At the top of the Commons page, search for UCSB PaCE

Step 4: Once you click on the UCSB PaCE Template 2.0 box, it will take you to a new page. On that page, on the right hand side, select the import/download button. 



Step 5: Once you select the import/download button, a list of your courses will appear. Select the course you want to import/download the template into. You can also select all of the courses. 

 

Step 6: Once you select the courses, at the bottom, select import into Course.



Step 7: Once you select the button, you will see a message that states, "You have successfully started the import‚Ä¶" 

 

Step 8: On the left hand side, select the dashboard button.



Step 9: Once on the home page, you will see the template. It should look like the image below. You will need to edit the different pages.

 

Step 10: Select the Edit button on the main home page.



Step 11: Once you select edit, you can adjust the text and the image. To edit the image, select the image/icon that looks like a picture. Select the UPLOAD image and upload your own headshot/image. 

 

Step 12: Scroll down and edit additional text - instructor name, title, company and course information.



Step 13: DO NOT EDIT ANYTHING AFTER THE COURSE INFORMATION. DO NOT CHANGE THE IMAGES.





Step 14: Go back to the home page. There are 9 boxes. You need to edit 7 out of the 9 boxes. The boxes that DOES NOT need to be adjusted/edited are the "Expectations and Policies" Box and "Canvas Help and Tutorial" Box. 



Step 15: When you click on each box, it is the same way to edit the text. Click on the EDIT button on the upper right hand corner and adjust the text. 

 

Step 16: You will also want to adjust your modules. The module tab is on the left hand side and it is also linked to the course content box.



Step 17: In the module tab, you can add/delete assignments, readings, etc.

CLICK HERE FOR VIDEO TUTORIAL

For more assistance, check out UCSB's Canvas Tutorial Help Page

Title: How does Open University help seniors graduate on time?
Body:
How does Open University help seniors graduate on time?

If you are a qualified graduating senior, you can take any outstanding courses in the fall, winter, or spring quarters through Open University. You do not need to wait for the summer quarter, which should help you graduate on time.

You must be in good academic standing and have department and college approval prior to enrolling through Open University.

Title: Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act
Body:
Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act

The University of California, Santa Barbara campus safety report entitled, "Dedicated to the Safety of Our Community" is published annually to provide safety policies, information, and statistics to its community and to prospective students and employees. Statistics on the reported occurrences of criminal activity are made public in accordance with the Jeanne Clery Disclosure of Campus Security Policy and Campus Crime Statistics Act (formerly the Student Right to Know and Campus Security Act).

For more information on this act and information regarding campus security and personal safety‚Äîincluding topics such as crime prevention, university police law enforcement authority, crime reporting policies, disciplinary procedures, missing students and emergency notification policies, registered sex offender information, and other matters of importance related to security on campus‚Äîvisit the UCSB Division of Student Affairs website. This website also contains information about crime statistics for the three previous calendar years concerning reported crimes that occurred on campus, in certain off-campus buildings or property owned or controlled by UCSB, and on public property within, or immediately adjacent to and accessible from the campus.

This information is required by law, provided by the Office of Student Life and the campus police department, and upholds the campus belief that a well-informed community is better served and safer. UCSB makes continual efforts to reduce campus crime and supports a reporting philosophy that encourages victims or witnesses to report all incidents immediately to either the UCSB Police or anonymously to a campus security authority. However, in cases of sexual assault, the university recognizes that reporting to law enforcement is a personal decision and respects the right of the survivor to make that decision.

Title: CPA Licensure Prep Program Refund Policy
Body:
CPA Licensure Prep Program Refund Policy

We understand that sometimes circumstances change and you may need to withdraw from the program. In order to assist you with this process, we have provided the following information on our refund policy.

Tuition Refund:

  • If you provide written notice of your intention to withdraw from the program 10 or more days before the program start date, you will receive a refund of your tuition, less a $40 processing fee.
  • If you provide written notice of your intention to withdraw less than 10 days before the program start date but before 5pm on the last business day before the program start, you will incur a $250 administrative fee in addition to the $40 processing fee.
  • Please note that there will be no refunds issued after 5pm on the last business day before the program start date. After that deadline, you can only ask for a withdrawal. You will receive a "No Credit" (NC) as your final grade.
  • If the program is cancelled due to low enrollment, all tuition and deposit fees will be fully refunded.

Deposit Refund:

  • The $100 deposit fee is non-refundable, except in the case where the program is cancelled due to low enrollment.
  • If the program is cancelled due to low enrollment, all tuition and deposit fees will be fully refunded.

We strongly encourage you to carefully consider your commitment to the program before making a final decision. If you have any questions or concerns about the program or refund policy, please do not hesitate to contact our program support team at help@professional.ucsb.edu

Title: Are credits earned through Open University transferable to a degree program at UCSB?
Body:
Are credits earned through Open University transferable to a degree program at UCSB?

Yes. Credits earned in Open University courses will be applied to UCSB degree programs, provided all policies and procedures are met.

Submitting transcripts: It is the student's responsibility to provide PaCE/Extension transcripts to the UCSB Office of the Registrar. Please see additional information on how to order a transcript here.

Title: What are the reporting requirements for Optional Practical Training?
Body:
What are the reporting requirements for Optional Practical Training?

All F-1 students approved and authorized for OPT must report all periods of employment, unemployment, and changes of address. Updates must be reported to UCSB Professional and Continuing Education within 10 days of the start of your OPT work authorization and within 10 days of any subsequent change. This includes the following:

  • Any change of your name, your residence, and/or mailing address.
  • The name and address of your first and any subsequent OPT employer(s). If you have more than one employer, you must report each employer's name and address.
  • The start date or end date of your employment.
  • Any change in the employer's name and address.
  • The name and address of any new employer, and the start date of your new employment.
  • Any period of unemployment, including those days between the end of one job and the start of the new job.
  • If you decide not to use OPT and depart the U.S. to return home or to a third country.
  • If you change to another nonimmigrant status in the U.S. (such as H-1B, E-3, G-4, TN, etc.), or obtain Permanent Resident status.

Please contact the Immigration Advisor at the Help Center to report any of the changes listed above.

Title: Safety in Isla Vista
Body:
Safety in Isla Vista

Members of the UCSB community are now receiving information about serious crimes when they occur on campus and in Isla Vista through UCSB Alert System timely warnings. Though the timely warnings can be alarming, they are intended to provide you with information to assist you in avoiding dangerous situations. Issuance of these warnings may help to identify at-large suspects more quickly. To register for the timely warnings, please visit the UCSB Alert System website and log in with your UCSBNetID.

UCSB is concerned about crime in Isla Vista and wants it to be a safe place for our students to live. UCSB's administration, the UCSB Police Department, and Associated Students are working closely with the Santa Barbara County Sheriff's Department, which has jurisdiction in Isla Vista. UCSB will continue to work with and support the Sheriff's Department and Isla Vista Foot Patrol in addressing issues related to student safety off-campus.

UCSB has many efforts already in place to provide safety education for students. Below is a listing of resources, as well as tips you can follow, to improve your own safety.

Isla Vista Safety Tips

    • Be aware of your surroundings.
    • Walk in pairs, especially at night, and/or utilize the UCSB Community Service Organization (CSO) escort service on campus and in Isla Vista by calling (805) 893-2000.
    • Call IV Foot Patrol (see below for phone numbers) to report crime, or if you notice suspicious, dangerous, or criminal behavior or activities.
    • Lock your doors and windows; don&'t leave valuables in vehicles, and always secure your bicycle.
    • If you rent in Isla Vista, talk to your property owner or manager about any security concerns on the property. If you need assistance or advice, visit the UCSB Community Housing Office or call (805) 893-4371.
    • Don&'t invite out-of-town friends to visit you in Isla Vista if you aren&'t willing to take responsibility for their behavior.
    • Don&'t allow people you don&'t know into your parties. Please visit UCSB Life of the Party for more tips on how to increase safety at parties.
    • Be careful near the cliffs along Del Playa where there are unfenced areas in some locations, and make sure your out-of-town guests are aware of the dangers.
    • Obey the law and local ordinances, including traffic and bike laws.

UCSB Campus and Community Safety Resources

Isla Vista Foot Patrol

    • Dial 9-1-1 in an emergency or to report suspicious or dangerous behavior in Isla Vista.
    • Call (805) 681-4179 for nonemergency information, questions, or to request an IV Foot Patrol officer for a group safety presentation.
    • Come to office hours with Lt. Ray Vuillemainroy on Mondays from 3-5 p.m. at IV Foot Patrol.

UCSB Police Department

    • Dial 9-1-1 in an emergency or to report suspicious or dangerous behavior on campus.
    • Call (805) 893-3446 for nonemergency information or to request a UC Police officer for a group safety presentation.
    • Visit the UCSB Police website for logs of daily incidents and crime prevention tips.
    • For safety videos created for UCSB, visit the UCSB Public Safety YouTube channel. 

UCSB Community Service Organization

    • Call (805) 893-2000 for safety escort service (walking or biking) on campus and in Isla Vista

UCSB CARE Program (formerly Rape Prevention Education Program)

    • Call (805) 893-3778 or visit the Women's Center on the first floor of Student Resource Building at UCSB

Remember that more than 80% of sexual assaults involve someone who knows the victim. The Campus Advocacy Resources and Education (CARE) staff members are available to meet with anyone who has been impacted by interpersonal violence.

Title: Registration Information: How Can I Enroll?
Body:
Registration Information: How Can I Enroll?

Online

You can enroll online 24 hours a day. Payments can be made using Mastercard, Visa or Discover. American Express cards are not accepted.

NEW STUDENTS: If you do not have a UCSB PaCE Student account yet, please follow these steps:

How to Create a New Account

1) Go to the PaCE Student Portal

2) Enter your email address where it says "I am a new user"

3) Click on "Create Account" and complete your Student Profile

4) Your User Name and your temporary password will be emailed to you once you complete your profile

5) Now you are ready to enroll. Go to the course you want to enroll in, click "Add to Cart" and follow the prompts to check out

On the phone

Please feel free to call our office at 805-893-4200 during regular business hours (Monday-Friday, from 9am to 5pm PST) so we can process your enrollment over the phone.

In person 

Our office is located at:

2160 Kerr Hall (2nd floor), UCSB
Santa Barbara, CA 93106-1110
Hours: 9 am-5 pm (PST), Monday-Friday.

We are closed on weekends and US Federal Holidays.

Title: Miscellaneous Fees
Body:
Miscellaneous Fees

Open University Late Enrollment/Drop

A late fee is charged for processing course enrollments after the established quarterly enrollment deadline. A drop fee is charged to submit a petition to leave a course after the published drop deadline. Please find our Open University Drop Policy here.

For Open University, you must submit a Petition for Late or Retroactive Enrollment if enrolling after the deadline.

*Exceptions to the published enrollment and drop deadline will be granted only in very unusual and compelling circumstances. Permission to enroll and drop courses after the deadline can only be granted by UC Santa Barbara Division of Professional and Continuing Education.

Open University Change of Grading Option

An administrative fee is charged for processing requests to change a course grading option from letter grade to pass/ no credit or vice versa.

To change a grading option for Open University, you must complete and submit a Request for Change of Grading Option.

Returned Check/Credit Card Chargeback

A fee is assessed for all returned checks. If a check is returned due to insufficient funds, you will lose the right to pay by check. A fee is also accrued for all credit card charge backs.

An administrative fee is charged for Optical Practical Training (OPT).

Body:
Retention of Student Records

You are strongly advised to carefully check your academic record quarterly. Any discrepancies in the academic record should be reported to the Registrar immediately. After one year, it is assumed that you will accept the accuracy of your academic record.

Title: What should I do if I wish to withdraw from the quarter and return home?
Body:
What should I do if I wish to withdraw from the quarter and return home?

You do have the option to withdraw from your classes. If you wish to do so, please contact our immigration advisor at help@extension.ucsb.edu as soon as possible. Your visa will be canceled and you will have to complete paperwork to withdraw from your courses.

You must then leave the U.S. within 15 days of withdrawing. Please understand you will not receive a grade for any work you have completed this quarter one withdrawing. Furthermore, you will receive an "F" if you fail to turn in the appropriate withdrawal paperwork.

Title: Why am I unable to access the Assignments menu in Big Interview?
Body:
Why am I unable to access the Assignments menu in Big Interview?

In some instances, your web browser may limit the functionality of the Assignments menu and other areas of Big Interview. For the best experience, we recommend that you download and use the Google Chrome web browser with Big Interview (issues may occur when using Safari). For the best user experience, we also recommend using a laptop or desktop device with Big Interview, configured with only one display (devices configured with multiple displays in "split screen" format may incur issues).

Title: Think "Safety First!"
Body:
Think "Safety First!"

Even though Santa Barbara and Goleta are very safe communities, you should always think "SAFETY FIRST!"

Follow these tips when going out:

    • Don&'t go alone! Go with a friend. Criminals often target people who are by themselves.
    • Be aware of your surroundings. If you see suspicious people around you, go to somewhere that has lots of light and people. Avoid dark deserted streets late at night.
    • Carry a cell phone with you all of the time. Know how to call 9-1-1 quickly. Be prepared to tell them where you are.
    • Avoid showing expensive jewelry or electronics. Crooks are looking for an easy or obvious victim. Items like iPods and flashy jewelry make tempting targets for thieves.
    • The drinking age is 21 in California. Do not drink and drive.

If you are an Open University student, you are not considered a matriculated UCSB student; instead you are considered a UCSB Extension student. Your Open University student status qualifies you for these benefits offered on UCSB's campus:

  • Recreation Center memberships are available for a quarterly fee. 
  • Use of main campus Library

Note: Students are not eligible for UCSB student health insurance, fee discounts on event tickets, or other privileges that matriculated students receive.

Title: Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Python Programming
Body:
Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Python Programming

Certificate Registration and Candidacy

UC Santa Barbara Extension/PaCE, in partnership with UC San Diego Extension, offers a certificate program in Python Programming. 

Certificate Requirements:
- 12 units total: 3 required courses, and 1 elective course
- Grade of C or higher in all completed courses

How to enroll in Certificate Program:
When you enroll in a single Python course, you are automatically enrolled in the Certificate. When all courses have been completed, you will receive a message from our office to claim your Certificate. You can keep track of your own course completion by logging into your student account.

If you have any questions at all, you can always contact us at help@professional.ucsb.edu.

Unless otherwise stated, you have 21 consecutive quarters (approximately five years) to complete your certificate requirements. You will be held to the certificate requirements in place at the time you pay your certificate fee. If the requirements for your certificate change, you can choose to complete the certificate under the new requirements. Because program requirements are usually updated to accommodate changing demands in a career field, you generally will not be allowed elect to complete the certificate under requirements that were discontinued prior to your registration in the program. Contact your program representative for more information.

Title: Open University Roadmap: Economics
Body:
Open University Roadmap: Economics

If you wish to enroll in ECON (Economics) classes offered through UC Santa Barbara Division of Professional and Continuing Education, follow the instructions below:

Step 1: Choose your Economics courses

  1. Review course availability on the Economics Department website. You can read the course descriptions on the UCSB General Catalog.

Note:

  • You are responsible for choosing courses in which you have already met the prerequisites. If prerequisites need to be confirmed, you will be contacted requesting more information.
  • Graduate level classes (numbered 200-299) are not available.

Step 2: Attend the first day of class and fill out the OU Application/Authorization form.

  • Go to the first class and ensure you are ready for the course material. If you feel you are not ready for the course, do not request it.

    Note: For ECON courses, do NOT contact the instructor for permission to attend class.     You do NOT need to obtain the instructor's or the Teaching Assistant's signature.

  • Drop off the OU Authorization form at the Economics Department Office, 2121 North Hall, as soon as possible. The Economics Department will return all forms to the Student Services Office.

Step 3: Enroll at Student Services Office, 2166 Kerr Hall

  1. Pick up your OU Authorization form at the Student Services Office, 2166 Kerr Hall.

  2. Look at your OU Authorization form. If it is:

    1. Signed by the Economics Department, enroll in the course at the Student Services, Office, 2166 Kerr Hall.
    2. Not signed by the Economics Department, choose another course.
    3. Not at the Student Services Office, continue attending class (lecture and the discussion section) until you find out whether or not your OU Authorization form will be signed by the Economics Department.

For undergraduate ECON courses, please see the ECON department website.

Body:

If you have been approved for WIOA funding towards education-related retraining or skill enhancement, first please review the list of Programs we offer on the CalJOBS website here.

Please make sure the approved funding covers the entire Program Cost. Please have your Case Specialist email a copy of the signed and approved ITA Worksheet or any similar document to help@professional.ucsb.edu confirming the Total Training Cost which will be reimbursed to PaCE. Title: Project Management Cert - FAQs and Responses
Body:
Project Management Cert - FAQs and Responses

How long does it take to complete the project Management certificate?

Most students take 1 - 3 years to complete a certificate program, depending on how much time they can devote to completing the coursework and how the courses are scheduled. You may proceed at your own pace, but you must complete all course requirements within 5 years from the date your first course ends.

What are the educational requirements to be accepted into the Project Management Certificate Program?

There are no educational requirements you need to meet prior to enrolling into our Project Management Certificate Program.

Can I complete this program in one year?

Yes, you can complete this program in one year.

When do classes normally meet; daytime, evenings, weekends?

Extension courses are designed for the working professional. We typically offer classes once a week in the evenings. Some project management courses are offered on Saturdays and online. Please refer to the class schedule to determine what day/time classes meet. Project Management Program Course Schedule

Can work experience substitute for classes?

No unfortunately work experience does not count towards our Professional Certificate requirements. Please refer to the Project Management Course Matrix for certificate requirements.

Can I enroll in classes without applying to the program?

Yes, you can take individual courses without enrolling into the Project Management Certificate Program.

Start by creating a student profile. Instructions on how to create a profile are located in our Help Center. Once you have created your profile, search for classes, click on the available course, then click ‚Äòadd to cart'. Proceed through the checkout process to enroll in the class.

How do the online classes work?

Thank you for your email and interest in the Project Management Certificate Program offered through UCSB Extension. Online instruction for the project management course is defined in one of 2 ways:

  • Online: These courses are facilitated entirely online via UCSB GauchoSpace, which is an interactive course management system. The course is self-paced, but there are still due dates and all assignments must be completed prior to the end date of the course.
  • Videoconference: Some courses offered in an online format have scheduled meeting times. These meeting times are hosted virtually through Zoom or similar video conferencing technology.

Is there a special certification or license to become a Project Manager?

Courses in our Project Management Professional Certificate Program cover the information in A Guide to the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK® Guide) that serves as the fundamental knowledge base for project management. To be eligible for a PMP® credential from the PMI®, you must meet specific guidelines that objectively measure experience, education, and professional knowledge. For specific information, visit the PMI website.

Title: How Do I Enroll for No Credit?
Body:
How Do I Enroll for No Credit?

You have the option to enroll in credit courses (professional courses only) on a no-credit basis. In this case, you may participate selectively in classroom activities. Noncredit students pay full fees and receive verification that they attended the course, but do not earn a grade or unit credit. If you choose the no credit grading option, "NC" is recorded for the course.

Note: If you wish to earn a professional certificate, you MUST enroll for credit.

Title: Why do I have to make so many formatting changes in the Smart Editor? [VMock]
Body:
Why do I have to make so many formatting changes in the Smart Editor? [VMock]

The Smart Editor is recommended for students who are creating a new resume or editing a basic-level resume. Because the Smart Editor requires you to apply a template to your resume before making changes, you may find that a number of formatting changes are needed to update your document. Though it can feel a bit inconvenient at first, this ensures that your resume is compliant with most Applicant Tracking Systems so that its information can be processed properly by modern recruiting technologies.

Title: What is the difference between BCBAs and BCaBAs?
Body:
What is the difference between BCBAs and BCaBAs?

So, what is the difference between BCBAs and BCaBAs? 

A Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA) holds a graduate-level degree and is able to provide behavior analytic services. A BCBA may also supervise BCaBAs and RBTs (registered behavior technicians). Typically, BCBAs provide consultation, direct services, training/workshops, and supervision. 

 

A Board Certified Assistant Behavior Analyst holds an undergraduate degree and is able to provide behavior analytic services under the direct supervision of a BCBA. BCaBA's may supervise RBTS.

Title: Cancellation and Withdrawal from International Student Programs
Body:
Cancellation and Withdrawal from International Student Programs

If you want to withdraw from an International Student Program you must do the following:

  1. Inform the immigration advisor by e-mail (help@professional.ucsb.edu).
  2. Withdraw from all courses.

Note: A complete withdrawal from all courses after the program has begun will result in the termination of your F-1 Student Visa status. This is an event that will warrant immediate departure from the U.S. Fee refund requests must be received in writing and are subject to International Student Programs Fees and adhere to International Student Programs Dates.

Title: Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Business Leadership
Body:
Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Business Leadership

A certificate is awarded upon completion of the 4 required courses totaling 16 units (or 144 hours of instruction), listed in the Program Schedule each with a letter grade of "C" / "Pass" or better. All requirements must be completed within five (5) years after the student enrolls in their first course. Students not pursuing a certificate are welcome to take as many individual courses as they wish.

There are no prerequisites for courses in this certificate nor is a bachelor's degree required.

To become an official candidate in the program, students need only register in one of the courses in the approved curriculum.

Request for Certificate Release

Application Fee $95.00

If all the Certificate requirements have been met, after your request is processed, you will receive an email notification from Parchment with a digital copy of your Certificate. A printed copy will be mailed via regular US Postal Service to the mailing address provided in your PaCE Student Profile 8-10 business days after receipt of the digital copy.

The $95 Certificate Release Fee is non-refundable. This Fee is required in order to receive a copy of your Certificate.

Click here to request your Certificate Release.

Title: FERPA (Student Records)
Body:
FERPA (Student Records)

In accordance to the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 and campus procedures implementing UC policies applying to the disclosure of information from student records, you have the right to inspect and review records pertaining to your capacity as a student; to have personally identifiable information from student records withheld from disclosure without prior consent for release (with exceptions as noted in Section 130 of the University policies); to inspect records maintained by the campus that include personally identifiable information from student records; to seek correction of student records through a request to amend the records or a request for a hearing; and to file complaints with the Department of Education regarding alleged violations of the rights accorded by the Federal Act.

Copies of the university's policies and campus implementation procedures and questions regarding various privacy regulations, including the text of the Privacy Act, can be addressed to the Santa Barbara Campus Information Practices Coordinator, Office of Equal Opportunity and Sexual Harassment/Title IX Compliance.

For the type and locations of student records maintained by the campus and titles and addresses of the officials responsible for the records, please refer to Policy 4005 in the UCSB Policies and Procedure Manual.

Title: What role does ABAI have in verifying courses?
Body:
What role does ABAI have in verifying courses?

Verified Coursework

ABAI works with institutions to identify and verify sequences of courses‚Äîknown as a Verified Course Sequence (VCS)‚Äîthat meet the BACB's coursework requirements. The ABAI VCS Directory includes all VCSs, VCS coordinators, content, hours, and dates for which the courses were verified.

* Not sure your coursework qualifies? If you are uncertain whether your coursework qualifies, you can request a preliminary coursework evaluation online prior to submitting a BCaBA Certification Application.

*Additional Resource

Title: Will ECON X units count toward the units required to receive financial aid?
Body:
Will ECON X units count toward the units required to receive financial aid?

Current UCSB matriculated students, who are eligible for financial aid, may be required to maintain a minimum of 12 academic units of undergraduate or graduate level courses. Please note that the ECON X professional units do not count toward that minimum.

Title: What are the English Language requirements for the TESOL Certificate?
Body:
What are the English Language requirements for the TESOL Certificate?

English requirements are the same of those for International Programs.

Title: What are the requirements for the course?
Body:
What are the requirements for the course?

  1. Students must be 18 years old by the first day of class.
  2. Starting with the Spring class of 2022, the CPR Certification (American Heart Association) will be included in the EMT program and is NOT required before you start the course. 
  3. Attendance: 100% class attendance is required as this is a California State EMS requirement.
  4. The course requires a significant amount of outside studying hours. Please expect 300-320 hours of out of class study and homework time over the course of two quarters, or 14-16 hours/week. If you are taking the Summer intensive class it is double the time.
  5. Purchase of 
  • The required textbook
  • Personal patient assessment tools (available as a "kit")
  • CastleBranch subscription 
  • EMSTesting test preparation subscription

Details will be shared at the first class session. Please find more information about the additional cost here. 

  1. The following are also required. Please wait until attending the course to complete them as there are specific required vendors. You may however, gather any proof of immunizations already completed.
  • Negative TB skin test or chest x-ray
  • Childhood immunizations:
    • MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella)
    • Varicella
    • Pertussis
  • Other immunizations (no exemptions accepted due to the clinical partnerships):
    • Covid-19
    • Influenza
    • Hepatitis B
  • 10 panel drug test
  • Criminal Background Check
  • Medical physical examination

All of the above course requirements must be completed by the 5th week of the first quarter in which a student is enrolled.  

  1. EMT Students must not have any facial hair that interferes with the wearing of an N95 mask. Facial piercings need to be removed and any visible tattoos covered for the ride-alongs with AMR. 
  2. Clinical observation hours can be located in Santa Barbara, Goleta, or Solvang and you are responsible to have transportation to the designated location.

Title: What is Open University?
Body:
What is Open University?

Open University serves quite a varied audience: community members, non-matriculated international students, nominated high school students, and UCSB seniors/de-matriculated students. Essentially, it opens the UCSB campus to people who are not earning degrees at UCSB. Every UC has a program like this to expand its courses to not just degree-seeking students. It is an effort to make UC education more available on the course level.

 

If students have the course pre requisites and/or academic experience to take the course, they can be approved for enrollment by the department advisor or individual professor. Please consult with your department chair to know who will approve/deny Open University enrollment forms.

 

If/when you approve, a copy of the form will be automatically sent to our office. Our Registrar will send this information to the main campus Registrar for official enrollment in e-grades. Then, Extension students will appear on your list at the very bottom (not alphabetized.) They will then need to be added to the Canvas site for the course.

We hope that you will consider these requests, as often, students are taking courses for degree completion, as well as out of general interest and desire.

Title: How do I apply for the ABA program?
Body:
How do I apply for the ABA program?

To apply to the ABA 5th edition program, please visit the Applied Behavior Analysis program page, click the "Apply Now" button, complete the questionnaire, and pay the $150 candidacy fee. If you are currently in a graduate program, you can send an unofficial transcript. If you have earned a graduate degree in a related field, please attach your official transcript to the application.

*Note: For the Assistant Behavior Analyst certificate program the Application is $45.
