Title: Can I travel internationally outside the U.S. during my program?
Body:
Can I travel internationally outside the U.S. during my program?

You may travel internationally outside the U.S. during your program, but be sure that you carefully read and follow the instructions below before you plan your trip. 

Travel Endorsement Signature:  A travel endorsement signature is required on page 2 of your I-20 if you are planning to travel outside the U.S. and re-enter at any time during your program of study. Please note that this includes short trips to Canada and Mexico, even if you are visiting for the day. Travel endorsement signatures are valid for a period of one year OR until the program end date indicated on page 1 of your I-20, whichever comes first.

The travel signature confirms to the U.S. Customs/border officer that we have authorized your international travel while you are participating in our program, which allows you to re-enter the United States. If you need a travel endorsement signature, stop by the Professional and Continuing Education Office with your I-20. Please plan to do so well in advance of your travel dates to be sure the office is open and that a staff member is available to authorize your international travel. When you travel internationally, even if only for the day, be sure to bring your valid (unexpired) passport with valid visa, and your I-20 with travel endorsement signature.

Mexico Travel Warning: The U.S. Department of State has issued warnings about the risk of traveling to certain locations in Mexico due to safety threats posed by organized criminal groups in the country. Please carefully review the most recent Mexico travel warning issued by the U.S. Department of State prior to your trip, even if you only plan on visiting for the day. 

If you plan to visit Canada: Visitors who do not need a visa to enter Canada will need an Electronic Travel Authorization (eTA) to fly to (or transit through) Canada. This is similar to ESTA (Electronic System for Travel Authorization) currently required for qualifying visitors to the United States. Applying is simple, inexpensive, and takes just minutes to complete. You can find more detailed information regarding applying to eTA on the Canadian government website.

60-Day Grace Period: At the conclusion of your program, you are given a 60-day grace period during which you may remain in the United States on an F-1 student visa. You are welcome to stay and enjoy Santa Barbara or to travel within the United States during this 60-day period immediately following the program end date indicated on your I-20. However, if at any time during this 60-day grace period you exit the United States, your F-1 student visa status will no longer be valid‚Äîeven if the expiration date on your visa is still valid. Should you wish to re-enter the United States, you will need to do so as tourist status. 

 

Please be advised that international travel is not recommended at this time due to the global pandemic and changing entry policies.

Title: How do I apply for an F-1 Visa?
Body:
How do I apply for an F-1 Visa?

Applying for the F-1 student visa may vary depending on the U.S. embassy or consulate you are working with. You will be required to pay a nonrefundable visa application fee. There is an online visa application available, which allows you to complete and print the Form DS-160 to take to your F-1 visa interview.

You can schedule your F-1 visa interview with the U.S. embassy or consulate. Visit the U.S. embassy's website to find the U.S. embassy or consulate location that is most convenient for you. Wait times for interview appointments vary by location, season, and visa category, so you should apply for your visa early. An F-1 student visa for the U.S. can be issued up to 120 days in advance of your course of study start date. However, you will only be able to enter the US with an F-1 visa 30 days before your start date.

The following documents are required for your F-1 visa interview:

  • I-20 Certificate of Eligibility Form provided by UCSB Professional and Continuing Education
  • Letter of admission provided by UCSB Professional and Continuing Education
  • Financial Support documents (current proof of support that would meet expenses for the program duration as indicated on Form I-20‚Äîi.e., bank statements, award letters, or loan approval letters)
  • Form DS-160 "Nonimmigrant Visa Application" available at your local embassy or consulate's website
  • A passport that is valid for at least six months beyond your program completion date
  • Two photos
  • Machine Readable Visa (MRV) fee, which is currently $160 USD
  • Receipt for payment of the I-901 SEVIS Fee

Additional documents may be requested to prove your eligibility for the F-1 student visa, including academic transcripts, diplomas, degrees, or certificates. Test scores such as the TOEFL, SAT, GRE, or GMAT may also be requested, as well as proof of your intent to depart the U.S. after your program is complete and proof of your financial stability.

Your F-1 visa interview will determine whether you are qualified to receive an F-1 student visa for the USA. Assuming that you have prepared the appropriate documents and meet all of the F-1 visa requirements, your visa will be approved at the discretion of the consular officer.

You may be required to pay a visa issuance fee. Digital fingerprint scans will be taken for records. Your passport will be taken so that you can get your visa and you will be informed when you can get it back, whether it's in person or in the mail.

Keep in mind that visa issuance is not guaranteed. Never make final travel plans until you have your visa approved.

For additional information on F-1 visas, visit the U.S. Department of State: Bureau of Consular Affairs Student Visa page. To learn more about U.S. consulates around the world, visit the U.S. Embassy's page.

Title: HR Management Certificate - FAQs and Responses
Body:
HR Management Certificate - FAQs and Responses

Are all 32 Units required to complete the Human Resources Management Certificate?

Yes, there are 5 required courses totaling 20 units and you'll need to choose from a variety of elective courses for a total of 12 units.

How do I apply for and take the test to obtain the HR Management Certificate?

UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) offers a professional certificate upon successfully completion of the program. The course offerings are designed to provide you with an understanding of all facets of human resources and may help prepare you for "certification" such as SHRM or HRCI.

For more information about the program please visit the certificate page: Human Resource Management

Are any of the courses for the Human Resources Certification offered online?

Courses are offered in a variety of methods; on UCSB Campus, online and blended. The Program Course Schedule matrix on each certificate page indicates the current plan for course offerings, organized by academic quarter and location. UCSB PaCE offers courses 4 times a year during fall, winter, spring, and summer. For academic quarter dates, click here.

Please note that the plan is subject to change based on course cancellations. For the most up-to-date information about course offerings and scheduled dates/times, visit the specific course description.

Can I transfer course credit between UCLA extension or other universities and UCSB PaCE?

Yes, you can transfer courses, limited to 8 quarter units, toward completion of this certificate program, if you earned a "C" or better for the course and it was completed within the last five years. Questions regarding eligibility for transfer should be requested through Student Services.

After completing and earning the HR Certificate, what HR position can I apply for?

Completion of a certificate program shows evidence to a current or future employer that you have recent professional-level training and development in a particular field. Most jobs in HR now require a bachelor's degree and completion of an HR Certificate. Review job descriptions for the kinds of positions you seek and make sure to complete elective courses in the program that complement the skills listed.

Do you need to have a bachelor's degree or any other certification to be able to get into the HR certificate program?

There are no prerequisites for admission to the HR Certificate Program. To apply click the "apply now" button on the certificate page, complete the online questionnaire and pay the $100 fee.

How long does it typically take to complete? How many units can I take at one time?

Completion of the Human Resource Management certificate program typically takes 2 years, but you have up to five years from the time you complete your first course to complete the program. Most students take one or two courses during any given quarter and there is no limit as to how many courses/units a student may enroll in each quarter. It is up to the individual depending on his/her time commitment.

Do you have any job assistance programs for those who complete the certificate? What area do you recommend starting in?

As a certificate candidate you have an opportunity to join a list serve where the program directors regularly post job opportunities from the local area.

We do recommend that our students enroll into the: Foundations of Human Resource Management, first. This sets the tone for the rest of the certificate program. However, our students are welcome to take any of the courses, as long as the student meets the published course requirements.

Are any classes offered online? What do SP and SU mean in the course schedule?

The Program Course Schedule matrix on each certificate page indicates the current plan for course offerings, organized by academic quarter and location. UCSB PaCE offers courses 4 times a year during fall, winter, spring, and summer. For academic quarter dates, click here.
Specifically, the initials SP stand for "Spring" Quarter and SU stands for "Summer" Quarter.

Title: UCSB Library Privileges
Body:
UCSB Library Privileges

International students enrolled through UCSB Professional and Continuing Education will have access to checkout privileges and library databases. The library privileges are included in the student services fees. In order to create a library account, go directly to the UCSB Library's circulation desk.

Title: Tax Credit 1098-T Form
Body:
Tax Credit 1098-T Form

The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 includes a number of educational tax benefits that may have an impact on students and their families. The act requires the university to report information on students to the Internal Revenue Service. For additional information on the Hope Scholarship Tax Credit and the Lifetime Learning Credit please refer to the IRS Publication 970 Tax Benefits for Education.

Information Returns

As required by law, UC Santa Barbara Division of Professional and Continuing Education (UCSB PaCE) will provide the IRS with information on students who have paid fees that qualify for the Lifetime Learning and Hope Scholarship Credits. Students who have consented in their PaCE Student Profile to electronic delivery of their 1098-T Form (printed copies are not available) will receive an email with detailed instructions on how to retrieve their 1098-T Form by February 1. 

If you have not consented by the time the 1098-T Forms are issued (first week of February), you will not receive a 1098-T Form. You will need to first update your consent status in your Student Profile and then send us a request at help@professional.ucsb.edu to receive your 1098-T Form.

 

Contact:

  • For detailed information about tax credit reporting service for students provided to the IRS by the Division of Professional and Continuing Education.
    Web: https://www.tsc1099.com/
    Phone: 1-888-220-2540
  • For more information on the Taxpayer Relief Act (U.S. Dept. of Education)
    Web: http://www.ed.gov/
  • The Internal Revenue Service
    Web: http://www.irs.ustreas.gov/
    Phone: 1-800-829-1040

Social Security Numbers

Students are prompted for their Social Security number at the time of enrollment to ensure accurate reporting to the IRS. Social Security number disclosure is mandatory to be eligible for the tax credit.

The university is required by federal law to report your SSN and other pertinent information to the Internal Revenue Service pursuant to the reporting requirements imposed by the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997. The university also will use the SSN you provide to verify your identity. This notification is provided to you as required by the Federal Privacy Act of 1974.

If you find that you have recorded an incorrect number, please provide us with written notice of the correct number at help@professional.ucsb.edu. If you plan to seek tax deductions for educational expenses, we urge you to save your receipts.

Veteran Information

Veterans and dependents of veterans: UC Santa Barbara Division of Professional and Continuing Education does not certify enrollment for student veteran benefits. The Open University Program is not approved for veteran benefits. For more information about approved enrollment with UCSB main campus (which is separate from UCSB PaCE), please contact the UCSB Office of the Registrar at (805) 893-8905, or visit www.registrar.ucsb.edu/veteran.htm.

Title: What is the difference between a matriculated UCSB student, and an Open University student?
Body:
What is the difference between a matriculated UCSB student, and an Open University student?

If you are a registered, matriculated UCSB student you are fully enrolled at UCSB and seeking a degree in major subject. Open University (OU) students have withdrawn from UCSB, do not pay campus-based service fees, and are completing a couple of units for their degree. These units are then applied to the major, and the official UCSB transcript, for degree completion. 

To become an Open University student through UCSB Extension, you must officially petition to withdraw from UCSB prior to enrolling in and taking Open University courses. For more information visit UCSB Registrar's page.

OU Students do not:

Have a perm number.
Have access to Gold.
Have access to Rec Cen, childcare, financial aid.
(you may pay for some select services on a non-registered student basis)

Since OU students do not have access to Gold, and registering for classes online, please see guidelines on enrolling here.

Title: ONLINE Course Explanation
Body:
ONLINE Course Explanation

Hello   ,

Thank you for your email and interest in the Child Life Program offered through UCSB Extension. To answer your question regarding how online instruction is defined:

  • All courses in the program are offered in an interactive online format.
  • Course materials are posted on GauchoSpace, UCSB's Moodle¬© course management system. All assignments and interactions with the instructor will occur through this online system.
  • You receive an email of instructions regarding creation of your UCSBnetID (approximately 3 weeks before the start date of the quarter). This UCSBnetID will be used as the login for GauchoSpace (GS) and the off-campus login for the library (to access online journals for your assignments).
  • On or before the first day of the quarter your instructor will contact you via email with information about getting started in the course. This email may come through the GS system, so it is important to set up this umail account correctly when you create your UCSBnetID. There is an option for having this umail forwarded to an email account that you check frequently, so please considering doing this.
  • Courses are 11 weeks long, scheduled with a start date and an end date. During this time you engage online with lectures, videos, readings, and with each other through an online discussion forum. There is no specific time that you need to be online. Instead you will complete assignments at your convenience, but by a specific due date.  

Please let us know if you have additional questions.

 

Kind regards,

Title: Employer/Agency-Paid Payments
Body:
Employer/Agency-Paid Payments

Employers or agencies that are providing funding for students to attend professional and continuing education classes must submit a purchase order (one per student per course) or other appropriate authorization to bill for fees along with a completed enrollment form. Both the purchase order and enrollment form must be submitted at least one week prior to the first meeting of the course. Without receipt for payment of the course or an enrollment verification card, you are prohibited from attending classes. In order to secure space in the requested classes, it is recommended that these documents be submitted as soon as possible once the decision to provide funding has been made.

Submit your purchase order to:
UCSB Division of Professional and Continuing Education (Attn. Student Services)
Mail Code 1110
University of California, Santa Barbara
Santa Barbara, CA 93106-1110

UCSB faculty and staff who want to recharge course fees to their campus department need to fill out a Financial Journal. Please contact our financial department for further assistance. Do not attend class until the required paperwork has been submitted to the Division of Professional and Continuing Education. For further information, call (805) 893-4200.

Title: Quarterly Email - Tax Reporting for F-1 Students
Body:
Quarterly Email - Tax Reporting for F-1 Students

Dear ISP Student,

This email serves to inform you that all non-immigrants in F, J, M or Q status are required to report to the U.S. tax service (known as the Internal Revenue Service or "IRS") each year that they reside in the U.S. in that particular status‚Äî even if they did not work during the prior year. UCSB Extension is unable to advise on tax issues. Please visit our Help Center for information and FAQs about Filing Tax forms as an International Student.

If you were in a study program in the U.S. for even one day during 2016, you have tax filing obligations. You will not necessarily need to pay taxes unless you were paid by a U.S. entity while working inside the U.S. or unless you received a US-issued scholarship during 2016. However, you must at least report your presence in the U.S. by submitting a Tax Form 8843 to the IRS. This is a legal requirement for F-1 students.

The tax filing deadline for filing Tax Form 8843 is June 15, 2017. The tax filing deadline for those of you who may have earned wages from a U.S.-based company is April 18, 2017. Please direct any questions or comments you may have by sending an email to: help@extension.ucsb.edu.

I wish you safe travels and many more wonderful opportunities in the years ahead.

Kind regards,

Title: Dealing with Homesickness
Body:
Dealing with Homesickness

Are you homesick? Perhaps you occasionally feel like you don't fit in? This is normal, and although everyone may seem like they are super confident and happy, many other students are going through the same thing. Homesickness is not unusual and it can be overcome!

When you start at a new university in the U.S., you face three significant personal challenges:

  • Leaving behind familiar routines, people, pets, and places
  • Adapting to new routines, people, and places
  • Speaking English, which is not your first language

What might help?

Try some of these tips to help overcome your homesickness, loneliness, or feelings of not belonging.

Talk to someone. Talk with your roommate or a friend. If you haven't yet made friends here, then try a counselor or contact your program director.

Get out of your room or apartment. It's incredibly easy to hide in your room at the university. But doing so prevents you from meeting new people, trying new things, and experiencing university life in general. Make sure you spend time out of your room‚Äîeven if it's just at the University Center, in your floor lounge, the library, or the beach‚Äîand get your mind on other things.

Call/Skype home. This may sound like common sense, but it can really help. The key factor, however, is not to call home all of the time. A few times a week is a good amount because it keeps you in the loop, but doesn't take away from your experience here. Keep the conversation positive,, but if you miss your friends, family, or partner, calling, seeing, and speaking with them can sometimes help ease the heartache.

Encourage friends and family to come and see you (if possible) in your new setting.

You are not the only homesick student at UCSB! Remember that many other people will be sharing similar feelings, although you may assume that they are doing fine! (You can't read their minds just as they can't read yours!)

You are allowed to feel sad and homesick! You are also allowed to be happy‚Äîit isn't being disloyal to those you miss!

Establish a balance between study and leisure: you are NOT expected to work ALL the time‚Äîyou would soon burn out. On the other hand, if you do not set aside enough time to study, you can very quickly get behind, which only adds to the stress!

Is time management a challenge? If keeping up with study and homework are proving too difficult, maybe you need to change your study skills, or improve your time management. This can help you feel more satisfied with what you do.

Remember to get enough food and sleep! These affect us emotionally as well as physically.

Make contacts and friends in class on campus and through shared activities, sport clubs, or interest groups. There are many clubs and societies within the university and the surrounding community, you are sure to find something that suits your particular interests. Many new people will also be joining‚Äîyou will not to be the only new person.

Give yourself time to adjust: Take time‚Äîyou don't have to get everything right straight away (nor do you have to rush into making major decisions about staying or leaving).

Seek Professional Help

If your homesickness or challenges interfere with your academic or personal well-being, seek help. Contact the following:

  • UCSB Social Work Services
    • Location: Student Health Center, UCSB campus
    • Call: (805) 893-3087 for an appointment
      Note: Your first visit is free (no cost)
  • UCSB Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS)
    • Location: Building 599 (Career Services)
    • Call: (805) 893-4411 for an appointment or to speak to an after-hours counselor.
      Walk-in visits are also available for urgent needs.

Adapted from: Dealing with Homesickness blog post, UCSB Housing & Residential Services.

Title: Course Locations
Body:
Course Locations

In-class professional courses are primarily held on the UCSB campus.

Online professional courses do not include in-class sessions.

Blended professional courses include both in-class and online sessions.

Open University courses: UCSB regular session courses are held on the UCSB campus.

Canvas Support Information

Title: How to transfer extension course credit for TMP X130F toward my degree at UCSB?
Body:
How to transfer extension course credit for TMP X130F toward my degree at UCSB?

The units for TMP X130F may count toward graduation units, but will not count toward students' overall GPA.

To earn degree or unit credit for X100 series courses taken through UCSB Professional and Continuing Education students must, upon course completion, order an official transcript from Extension and have it sent to the UCSB Office of Admissions at admissions@sa.ucsb.edu

Title: Department of Rehabilitation (DOR)
Body:
Department of Rehabilitation (DOR)

If you have received funds from the Department of Rehabilitation to enroll in a PaCE Program, please select the Program you are interested in and then email us at help@professional.ucsb.edu so we can create a Proposed Educational Plan listing all the courses you selected and the fees associated with the Program. Once your DOR Counselor approves the Proposed Educational Plan and we receive the DOR Authorization Form covering the Program fees, we can proceed with enrollment.

All the required paperwork must be received at least 4 weeks prior to the first class meeting. Requests received outside this timeline will be considered for the following quarter.

PaCE does not defer fees. Applicants who are not fully funded by their work source center will be required to pay the difference in full at the time of enrollment.

Title: Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - TMP
Body:
Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - TMP

A certificate is awarded upon completion of the 5 required courses totaling 18 units (or 162 hours of instruction), listed in the Program Schedule each with a letter grade of "C" or better and an average grade of B or better across all courses . All requirements must be completed within five (5) years after the student enrolls in his/her first course. Students not pursuing a certificate are welcome to take as many individual courses as they wish.

To become an official candidate in the program, students must have upper-division standing and complete the Program Application. 

To receive a certificate of completion, upon completion of all required courses, students must submit a Request for TMP Certificate Release.

 

For additional information for how to transfer credit for TMP X130F toward your UCSB Degree: click here

Title: Do I get a Perm number?
Body:
Do I get a Perm number?

No, you will not get a perm number. Perm numbers are only given to students who earn their degrees at UCSB.

Title: Who is Eligible for the Young Scholars Program?
Body:
Who is Eligible for the Young Scholars Program?

Qualified high school students in the Santa Barbara area are nominated by their school guidance counselors or principals to participate in Young Scholars Program. Students may NOT enroll directly in the program. To be considered for Young Scholars Program, students must be mature, capable of handling university-level course work, be pursuing a rigorous college-preparatory study and be performing at an exceptionally high level.


Strong candidates are students who have exhausted what is available in one or more subject areas at their school or who wish to study a subject not available at their high school. Qualified homeschooled students should review all the guidelines regarding nominations provided in the FAQs here.

Title: Can I Park on Campus?
Body:
Can I Park on Campus?

Parking permits are required to park on the UCSB campus. Weekday visitors will need to buy a regular campus permit from 7:30 a.m.-5 p.m., Monday through Friday. There also are parking fees in effect for weeknights after 5 p.m. and all day on weekends. Individual daily and weekend permits may be purchased from permit dispensers located throughout campus parking lots. You may purchase a monthly, evening, or weekend pass from the permit dispensers or from the UCSB Transportation & Parking Services office.

Parking rates and regulations are subject to change. Please check the Parking Services website or call (805) 893-7275 for detailed information on current permit rates, requirements, and parking regulations. Parking infractions are subject to citation.

Title: Emergency Information
Body:
Emergency Information

Emergencies can come without warning at any time. Being prepared physically and psychologically to handle unexpected accidents or disasters is an individual as well as an organizational responsibility. Your safety is of primary importance to UCSB.

Call the Campus Emergency Information (Toll Free) number at 888-488-UCSB to get the latest status of the campus during a major emergency. The UCSB Emergency page has been created to help you be more prepared in the event of future emergencies.

Breaking news updates will be available on the main UCSB website as soon as possible.

If we are asked to evacuate the building, where do we go?
Each campus work and living area has posted "Building Specific Emergency Information." This information is available to all members of the campus community who use those areas. Please familiarize yourself with this data as well as the actions to take in the UCSB Emergency Information Flip Chart. In addition, it's important to use this knowledge in combination with the guidance of emergency workers.

For immediate life or health-threatening emergencies dial 9-1-1 from campus phones.
For medical assistance that is not life threatening (injuries not threatening to life or limb), please visit UCSB Student Health.

Earthquake

Should an earthquake occur, be prepared with the following knowledge. (Learn more at UCSB Emergency Response Procedures.)

OUTSIDE

    • Get to an open area away from trees, buildings, and power lines.

VEHICLE

    • Pull to the side of the road away from underpasses, bridges, and buildings.
    • Remain in the vehicle until the shaking stops. Do not leave the vehicle if a power line has fallen on or near it.

INSIDE

    • Stay away from windows and get under a desk or a table.
    • Duck, cover, and hold.
    • In a hallway, sit against the wall and protect your head with your arms.
    • In an auditorium, duck between the rows of seats and protect your head.
    • Wait inside until the shaking stops, then evacuate the building and go to your building emergency assembly point.
    • Do not use elevators for evacuation.
    • Designated personnel should assist individuals with mobility disabilities to a safe location, e.g., an enclosed stairwell landing with a ground level exit to the exterior or, if obstructed, an office space with a door.
    • Report to your Department Safety Representatives (DSR). The DSR will complete a department status report and transmit it to the campus Emergency Operations Center (EOC).
    • Do not re-enter the building until authorized to do so by emergency response personnel.

Tsunami
Should a tsunami occur, be prepared with the following knowledge. (Learn more at UCSB Emergency Response Procedures.)

If you feel a strong earthquake, keep calm and quickly move to higher ground away from the coast. Most of the UCSB campus should not be affected by tsunamis, except for the beach and lagoon areas. A strong earthquake can generate a tsunami within minutes. However, most tsunamis are formed by earthquakes that have occurred hundreds or even thousands of miles away. These earthquakes are not felt locally and thus provide no advanced warning to residents. "Tsunami waves" can travel through the water at speeds of up to 500 mph, and are sometimes preceded by a noticeable rise or fall of coastal waters.

Note: Do not use Highway 217 to evacuate during a tsunami warning due to its low elevation.

Title: Salary BCBA/BCaBA
Body:
Salary BCBA/BCaBA

BCBA Average Salary

Employers typically require their applied behavior analysis (ABA) professionals to:
1. Graduate from accredited applied behavior analysis programs (MEd degree)
2. Pass the national Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA) exam

While the BCBA average salary is $56,730, nationally, about one-third of Board Certified Behavior Analysts receive salaries above $75,000 per year. Some in high-demand areas make more than $145,000 per year.

BCaBA's Average Salary

Since BCaBA is a certification that is available to people in many professions, it can be hard to nail down a definitive salary. An average salary for a BCaBA is around $45,000 each year and these salaries are for those primarily employed in educational and scientific jobs. Generally speaking, with a BCaBA you can expect to make a little more than someone in the same job that isn&'t certified.

There are other fields that pay more but require more education and experience as well. For example, psychologists and sociologists, professions that are among those whose members hold BCaBA credentials, make around $80,000.

Title: How Do I Access PaCE Disability Services?
Body:
How Do I Access PaCE Disability Services?

Procedures For Requesting Disability Services for PaCE Programs/courses

Step 1: As early as possible, but no later than three weeks before any instruction begins, contact us at help@professional.ucsb.edu with your written request for Disability Services detailing the specific need and the course/s you need the special services for.

Step 2: The following documentation is required in order to receive Disability Services:

  • A written request outlining your needs and describing your limitations due to disability as covered under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 or Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.
  • Written notification on official letterhead from a physician, certified specialist or professional counselor, verifying your disability and outlining any need for special services. The documentation from your treating practitioner must be no more than 6 months old, meaning you must have been seen by him/her in the last 6 months. Depending on your needs, additional documentation may be requested.

Please note that if you are a current UCSB student already registered with UCSB Disabled Students Program, you will still need to contact PaCE directly to request Disability Services since UCSB DSP does not provide accommodations for PaCE Programs/courses. UCSB DSP only provides accommodations for UCSB academic courses. When sending your written request to PaCE, please provide the same medical documentation you submitted to UCSB DSP.

Step 3: A plan will be determined for providing you with services, and a timeline will be established for when services will begin. Services will only be arranged once you provide payment in full for Professional and Continuing Education course(s).

Note: Written requests that are received later than two weeks before instruction begins may limit our ability to provide you with the requested services in time for the first day of class.

Title: How can I get additional resume uploads in my VMock account?
Body:
How can I get additional resume uploads in my VMock account?

Your VMock account automatically resets with ten (10) resume uploads in the fall quarter of every academic year. To request additional resume uploads, please email support@vmock.com for a quick reply.

Title: Instructor Change
Body:
Instructor Change

Individuals who teach for UCSB Professional and Continuing Education have been chosen based on the following criteria:

  • Professional experience
  • Academic preparation
  • Teaching ability

The majority of instructors are working professionals who teach on a part-time basis, although full-time UC faculty and other college and university faculty also teach professional and continuing education courses. On occasion, and for reasons beyond the division's control, last-minute instructor changes may occur.

Open University Courses
The campus academic departments appoint UCSB instructors. On occasion, departments will appoint different instructors from those listed on the Schedule of Classes.

Title: How to Transfer My Course
Body:
How to Transfer My Course

Transferring Courses
If you would like to transfer from one course to another, you must submit a request in writing by using our help request form. Because a transfer is considered a drop/add, you must submit the request before the published refund deadline of the course you are currently enrolled in. Your request must include the following: 

  • Your name
  • Your student ID number (found on the homepage of your student profile)
  • The section ID number and title of the course you would like to drop
  • The section ID number and title of the course you would like to add
  • The best phone number and e-mail address to reach you

If the transfer results in a balance due, we will contact you for payment before processing your request. Any difference in course fees is assessed and due at the time of the transfer.

Title: Who can take these courses?
Body:
Who can take these courses?

Any UCSB student or community member is eligible to enroll in this program so long as they have completed the required program prerequisites with a C grade or higher. 

In some cases, subject to PaCE approval, equivalent courses taken at other institutions may be accepted as valid substitutions for prerequisite course requirements.

To be admitted to the program, students first need to complete the Strategic Investments Application.

Title: As a UCSB senior, am I eligible to take Open University courses?
Body:
As a UCSB senior, am I eligible to take Open University courses?

Yes, please check the following requirements:

  •  You are currently not registered. If you are, then you need to DE-register from the main campus.
  •  If you are an international student, please contact us at help@extension.ucsb.edu for visa and language requirements.
  •  If your academic standing is one of the following: academically disqualified, dismissed by dean's action, subject to disqualification, reinstatement probation, you will need a Letter of Approval to be completed and signed by the advisor and sent to help@professional.ucsb.edu for review.

However, if you are denied access to the UCSB campus by the court, university, or police order you are NOT eligible to enroll.

Title: How do I change my name in VMock?
Body:
How do I change my name in VMock?

If you are logging into VMock for the first time, your name in VMock is displayed as your Preferred Name from your student records through the Office of the Registrar.

If you have previously logged into VMock and your Preferred Name was not displayed, you are able to update this information permanently by clicking on your Account in the upper right corner of VMock and selecting your Name.

For further questions, please contact help@professional.ucsb.edu

Title: Open University Roadmap: Engineering
Body:
Open University Roadmap: Engineering

If you need to enroll into ENGR (Engineering) classes offered through UC Santa Barbara Division of Professional and Continuing Education, follow the instructions below:

  1. Contact the instructor early to verify prerequisites.
    • Check out the course descriptions and prerequisite courses for undergraduate and graduate courses on the College of Engineering's website (go to the specific department in which you want to take courses). Note that the course schedules are also on the individual department's website.
    • E-mail your instructor and state what prerequisite courses you have already completed and attach transcripts and course descriptions. Very important: Go to class on the first day of class and talk directly with your instructor. Be sure to take the Open University Authorization form with you.
    • If you don't know how to contact your instructor, e-mail the advisors in the specific departments.
  2. Ask your instructor (and if necessary, the Teaching Assistant) to sign and date the Open University Authorization form.
    • On the first day of class, after having made sure that you meet the course requirements and that there is room in the course, this form will need to be signed and dated by the instructor of each course!
    • Please note: A Teacher's Assistant (TA) signature alone does not qualify as instructor approval! If a Teaching Assistant is teaching the course, the Teaching Assistant must also sign the form before the ENGR advisor signs it.
  3. Once signed by the instructor, bring the OU Authorization form to the individual department's advisors and ask them to sign it as well.
  4. Once both signatures are obtained, return the OU Authorization form(s) to the Student Services Office, 2166 Kerr Hall to pay your course fees and finalize your enrollment.

Please note: for CHEMICAL ENGINEERING COURSES, PLEASE e-mail a list of your desired courses and your transcripts directly to the advisor BEFORE asking the professor!

Title: Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Introduction to Global Business
Body:
Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Introduction to Global Business

A certificate is awarded upon completion of the 3 required courses totaling 12 units (or 144 hours of instruction), listed in the Program Schedule each with a letter grade of "C" / "Pass" or better. All requirements must be completed within five (5) years after the student enrolls in their first course. Students not pursuing a certificate are welcome to take as many individual courses as they wish.

There are no prerequisites for courses in this certificate nor is a bachelor's degree required.

To become an official candidate in the program, students need only register in one of the courses in the approved curriculum.

Request for Certificate Release

Application Fee $95.00

If all the Certificate requirements have been met, after your request is processed, you will receive an email notification from Parchment with a digital copy of your Certificate. A printed copy will be mailed via regular US Postal Service to the mailing address provided in your PaCE Student Profile 8-10 business days after receipt of the digital copy.

The $95 Certificate Release Fee is non-refundable. This Fee is required in order to receive a copy of your Certificate.

Click here to request your Certificate Release.

Title: Sexual Harassment
Body:
Sexual Harassment

What is Sexual Harassment?
Unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, and other verbal or physical contact of a sexual nature constitute sexual harassment when:

    • Submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term or condition of instruction, employment, or participation in other university activity,

OR

    • Submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as a basis for evaluating an individual,

OR

    • Such conduct has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's performance, or creating an intimidating or hostile university environment.

Sexual Harassment May Include:

    • Derogatory remarks about one's clothing, body, or sexual activities based on gender
    • Disparaging remarks, jokes, and teasing based on gender
    • Verbal harassment or abuse
    • Subtle pressure for sexual activity
    • Unnecessary touching, patting, or pinching
    • Demanding sexual favors accompanied by overt threats concerning such things as one's job, grades, letters of recommendation, or promotion
    • Physical assault

UCSB Procedures for Sexual Harassment Complaints

Federal and state laws, as well as University of California system wide and Santa Barbara campus policies, prohibit sexual harassment in an educational setting. As members of the university community, UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) faculty and students are governed by these same policies. Grievance procedures designed specifically for this form of discrimination apply to students in regular UCSB courses and in UCSB PaCE courses. UCSB procedures for sexual harassment complaints are available on the Office of Equal Opportunity page. Further information/assistance can be obtained from Ariana C. Alvarez, Associate Director and Sexual Harassment/Title IX Compliance, University of California, 3217A Phelps Hall, (805) 893-2546.

Title: Can I take courses without being registered in a certificate program?
Body:
Can I take courses without being registered in a certificate program?

It is highly recommended to enroll in an OSHA certificate program once you have determined which program is appropriate for you. From the date of your registration in the certificate program, you have five years to complete the required coursework.

Title: Definition of Full Time Status
Body:
Definition of Full Time Status

Full Time Status for Verification

UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) provides official verification for students enrolled in our UCSB PaCE courses and programs. Enrollment status is determined as follows:

12.0 units or more is equivalent to full time status
6.0 - 11.9 units is equivalent to half-time status
5.9 units or less is equivalent to less than half-time status

Title: Driver License and Identification Card Information
Body:
Driver License and Identification Card Information

You have two options for driving in California:

1. Possess a valid driver license from your home country (country of residency).

Note: In addition to your valid home country's driver license, an International Driving Permit (IDP) is strongly recommended. The IDP is a translation of information contained on your home country's driver license. The State of California does not recognize an IDP as a valid driver license. The IDP along with your valid home country's driver license must be presented as needed. You will have to obtain your IDP in your home country before arriving in the U.S.

2. Obtain a California Driver License

    To obtain a California Driver License, see: How to Apply for a Driver License.

Note: Motor vehicle insurance is mandatory in California.

Identification Card

An Identification Card is recommended so you do not have to carry your passport with you at all times during your stay in California. You may obtain your Identification Card through the State of California Department of Motor Vehicles. To apply, see: How to Apply for or Renew an Identification Card (ID).

Additional Information for Drivers of All Ages
It is illegal to drive after consuming excessive alcohol in any form (including medications such as cough syrup), or taking any drug (including prescription medications), or using any combination of alcohol or drugs that may impair your ability to drive.

Blood Alcohol Concentration (BAC) Limits
It is illegal for any person to operate a vehicle with the following:

    • BAC of 0.08% or higher, if the person is age 21 or older
    • BAC of 0.01% or higher, if the person is under age 21

If you operate a vehicle violating these rules, the DMV can take an administrative action against your driving privilege after you are detained or arrested and the court may take a separate action (suspend, revoke, or delay the license) for the same offense. The court's action may involve payment of a fine, jail time, suspension, or revocation of your driving privilege and completion of a DUI program.

The above information is an excerpt from the California Department of Motor Vehicles, California Driver Handbook.

Title: Can I earn continuing/professional units at Open University?
Body:
Can I earn continuing/professional units at Open University?

When taking courses at UCSB through our Open University program, you will earn academic credits that are transferable to other academic programs and that may be applied to UCSB degree programs. If you're looking to earn professional-level (post-baccalaureate) credits, our professional certificate programs are for you!

UC Santa Barbara Division of Professional and Continuing Education is fully accredited by the WASC Senior College & University Commission (WSCUC). All courses in the certificate program are approved for professional-level, post-graduate credit. This type of credit is typically recognized by government and industry for full or partial tuition funding or reimbursement.

Title: May I Take Unlimited Courses at the Discounted Rate?
Body:
May I Take Unlimited Courses at the Discounted Rate?

Yes. As long as you apply, submit valid proof of residency, and are approved, you may take all your courses at the discounted rate.

Body:
Can I take more than the 5 courses required for the program completion?

Title: Quarterly Email - Travel Outside U.S. at End of Quarter
Body:
Quarterly Email - Travel Outside U.S. at End of Quarter

Dear ISP Student:

As the end of the Fall quarter draws near, I want to take this opportunity to mention a few issues related to international travel for F-1 visa students.

Your program end date (the last day of your last quarter of study) is indicated on page 1 of your I-20. At the end of your last quarter of study, F-1 students are given a 60-day grace period during which you may remain in the United States. You are welcome to travel within the United States during this 60-day period immediately following the program end date indicated on your I-20. However, if at any time during this 60-day period you exit the U.S. , your F-1 student visa status will no longer be valid (even though the expiration date on your visa may be in the future). Should you wish to re-enter the U.S., you will need to do so in visitor (tourist) status.

If you plan to leave and re-enter the U.S. following the completion of your program and you are a citizen of a country that does not require a visa to visit the U.S. as a tourist (Visa Waiver Program), you will need to register online with the ‚ÄòElectronic System for Travel Authorization' (ESTA) program which will allow you to enter the U.S. as a visitor (tourist) for a period of up to 90 days. Please check the ESTA website for a listing of the current Visa Waiver countries and for instructions on ESTA registration procedures.

If you plan to leave and re-enter the U.S. following the completion of your program and you are not from a visa waiver (ESTA eligible) country, you will need to visit an American embassy or consulate outside the U.S. to apply for a B-2 visitor (tourist) visa in order to be able to re-enter the U.S.

Many of you are continuing on to the Winter quarter 2017. If you wish to travel internationally during the holiday break, please be sure you have a travel authorization signature on page 2 of your I-20 before you leave the U.S. This signature will allow you to re-enter the U.S. to resume your studies.

If you have any questions, or if you have a situation that is different than those I mentioned above, please feel free to contact me directly.

Kind regards,

Title: MOU Guidelines for partner institutions
Body:
MOU Guidelines for partner institutions

UCSB International Programs has many partners throughout the world. As we expand our relationships with educational institutions, it is important to formalize such agreements in a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU)

The general procedures for signing an MOU with our institution are as follows:

Step1: Contact UCSB International Programs to show your willingness.

Step 2: Review Template Memorandum of Understanding
-UCSB International Programs' representative will contact you and send a template MOU for your review. After reviewing the template, you will provide your institution's official name and acronym and the full names and titles of the official representatives. 

Step 3: Print Finalized Memorandum of Understanding
-Once your institution provides the information above and approves the template, UCSB International Programs will prepare an original MOU for the signature of both parties.

Step 4: Secure Signatures
-The MOU, signed by UCSB International Programs, will be sent by express mail to your institution for counter-signature. Once it is signed, please return an original, fully-signed copy to UCSB International Programs.

Title: How do I properly convert my resume to PDF when uploading to VMock?
Body:
How do I properly convert my resume to PDF when uploading to VMock?

In Microsoft Word, convert your resume by clicking on File and Save As, then select the dropdown menu for Save as Type to choose PDF and Best for Printing. In Google Docs, click on File and Download to choose PDF Document as your file type. It is generally not recommended to use other software (e.g. Adobe InDesign, Adobe Photoshop, Canva) to create traditional resumes, due to PDF compliance issues with Applicant Tracking Systems.

Title: Unit and Enrollment Reminder
Body:
Unit and Enrollment Reminder

  1. Enrollment
    Please be flexible in your choice of classes. Enrollment in classes is not guaranteed. Enrollment in UCSB Academic classes will be finalized in the third week of the quarter.
    To ensure that you maintain visa status and achieve your academic goals, you may initially have to attend more classes that you will ultimately enroll in.

  2. Unit Requirement per Quarter for F-1 students:
    Minimum:
    In order to maintain the requirements of your F-1 Visa status, you must take a minimum of:
    12 units in undergraduate or combined undergraduate, graduate, and professional-level courses (covered by flat fee tuition)
    or
    8 units in graduate courses (covered by flat fee tuition)

    Maximum:
    Generally, we advise not to take more than a maximum of:
    16 units in undergraduate or combined undergraduate, graduate, and professional-level courses (additional fees required)
    or
    12 units in graduate courses (additional fees required)

    As UCSB terms are quarters (3 months) and not semesters (6 months), the work load for students can be quite high. In order to perform well in class and receive good grades, we generally do not recommend to take more than 16 units per quarter (for undergraduate courses) and 12 units for graduate courses.

  3. Academic Standards
    1. For Academic Studies (UCSB/Open University Courses):
      You must maintain an overall Grade Point Average (GPA) of 2.7 (B-) or higher and may not receive more than one grade of B- or lower in graduate classes.
      If you do not maintain these standards, you will be subject to Academic Probation or Disqualification.
    2. For Professional Studies (UCSB Professional Courses):
      You may not receive more than two No Credit (NC) grades.
      If you do not maintain this standard, you will be subject to Academic Probation or Disqualification.

  4. Enrollment Procedures
    Enrollment Deadlines for UCSB Academic Courses

Title: NEW! 25 % OU Employee Discount
Body:
NEW! 25 % OU Employee Discount

UCSB Employee Discount

Employee discounts on academic courses offered by main campus are provided to university staff and faculty in order to encourage campus employee professional and personal development.

UCSB faculty and staff who are employed at least 50% time in career positions are eligible to receive a 25% discount. Discounts must be requested at the time of enrollment (a copy of the staff ID card must accompany the enrollment), and will not be applied retroactively. Discounts are taken off the standard course fee. In order to receive the UCSB employee discount, the following must occur:

  1. Faculty and staff must provide proof of eligibility by providing a current UCSB staff card and a photo ID at the time of enrollment. Eligibility is subject to verification.
  2. Departments paying fees through a recharge must contact UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) to verify the applicability of the discount BEFORE deducting 25% from the standard fee.

Title: Does your program help me with the Child Life certification?
Body:
Does your program help me with the Child Life certification?

UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE)'s Child Life program is a stepping stone to help you reach the next step towards becoming a certified child life specialist. Our courses have been reviewed, earned pre-approval, and are listed on the Association of Child Life Professionals Programs Offering Pre-Approved Courses.

THE CERTIFIED CHILD LIFE SPECIALIST (CCLS) credential is the exclusive certification issued by the Association of Child Life Professionals (ACLP). The requirements for becoming a CCLS include completing at least 10 academic courses, submitting coursework evaluation, accruing a minimum of 600 clinical internship hours, and passing the Child Life Professional Certification Examination administered by ACLP. For more information, please visit the Association of Child Life Professionals website.

According to the Association of Child Life Professionals, "applicants must have completed a total of 10 college-level courses in child life or a related department/subject including a minimum of one child life course taught by a Certified Child Life Specialist (CCLS)."

ED X370.2: Child Life: Introduction to Theory and Practice is taught by a CCLS and meets the six required topics of study set forth by the Association of Child Life Professionals. Upon successful completion of this course, the Child Life Course Verification Form is issued.

Title: What do I do if the course I want to enroll in is full (has no space)?
Body:
What do I do if the course I want to enroll in is full (has no space)?

If a class is full, you may still attend the course, and go to the first class session and ask the instructor if you may enroll. There is a 3 week enrollment period, so you may end up getting accepted into the course in proceeding weeks. We encourage you to continue attending until you are told it is completely full, or you are formally admitted. 

In some courses, there is opportunity to be placed on a waitlist. If there is a wait list, the professor will refer you to the department office and advisor.

Title: Can a Student Participate in the Young Scholars Program After She/He Graduates from High School?
Body:
Can a Student Participate in the Young Scholars Program After She/He Graduates from High School?

Young Scholars Program is designed for high school students who are ready for university-level classes, and need academic credit. Graduation from high school marks the end of participation in the Young Scholars Program.   To discuss the procedure and implications for enrolling in UCSB courses after high school graduation, please contact the UCSB admissions office.

Title: On Campus Student Health Center
Body:
On Campus Student Health Center

While a student at UCSB, you may seek medical care at UCSB Student Health, which is located on campus. For more information about the health facility, take the video tour of UCSB Student Health at the bottom of the home page, and review the After Hours Care documentation. When you visit UCSB Student Health you will need to do the following:

  • Present your insurance ID card
  • Pay all fees
  • Request an itemized medical bill
  • Submit a claim along with your itemized bill to your insurance company

Note: Typically, the deductible is waived if you first seek treatment or are referred by UCSB Student Health.

Claim Form is here.

Title: Discounts
Body:
Discounts

Discounts

UC Santa Barbara Division of Professional and Continuing Education has several discount opportunities that are available for students. However, discounts may only be used one at a time (discounts may not be combined). Please always check the course/program page for specific discount policy stipulations and deadlines.

Early Bird Discount

A $50 discount is given to students who pre-enroll before the early bird date listed on each designated 3 or 4 unit course. If you enroll online, be sure to click on the "Early Bird Discount" button. To qualify, enrollment must be paid in full by the early bird fee deadline, the 15th of the month before the beginning of the quarter. Early Bird Deadlines for each quarter:

  • Fall: September 15
  • Winter: December 15
  • Spring: March 15
  • Summer: June 15

Group Discount

Companies or employers who enroll and pay for four or more participants in the same professional development course at the same time may receive a 25% discount off the standard enrollment fee. Online enrollment is not available for group affiliation discounts. To receive your discount, please send an email with your phone number and email to help@professional.ucsb.edu. A member of our Customer Support team will contact you to arrange a convenient time to assist with enrollment. The discount must be requested at the time of enrollment and will not be applied retroactively. If the number of students enrolled using the discount drops below three, standard fees will apply. Certain courses, such as those that include computer lab activities or charge for textbooks and/or materials may be excluded from this policy.

UCSB Undergraduate and Graduate Students Discount

UCSB matriculated Undergraduate and Graduate students are eligible for a 25% discount on PaCE professional courses (exclusions apply, please see list below) and on campus academic courses. This discount is only available if a UCSB student is officially registered and until a UCSB student graduates from UCSB. If the preferred course starts after the student graduates from UCSB, then the student is not eligible to receive this discount. As with other discounts, this discount is not stackable with any other promotions or discounts. 

Please do not self-enroll if you want to take advantage of this discount. 

In order to receive this discount, you will need to first fill out and submit this Application. If your Application is approved, you will receive an email with a discount code which you will use when enrolling in your preferred course/s. This discount code is valid for the current academic year (Fall to Summer) only. A new Application will need to be submitted for each new academic year.

The following Programs are eligible for this discount:

  • ABA (Exception: the Supervision course, Study Prep Program course, ED X309D.5, and all courses in Behavior Support and Systems Program are not eligible for this discount)
  • Business & Professional Accounting
  • Business Administration
  • Business Communication & Law
  • Business Leadership
  • Child Life (Exception: the Child Life Prep Program course is not eligible for this discount)
  • Digital Marketing
  • Hospitality Program
  • Human Resource Management
  • Infrared Programs
  • Global Business
  • Open University
  • Paralegal Studies
  • Project Management
  • Python Programming
  • Web Development

The following Partnership Programs are NOT eligible for this discount:

  • Technology Management (TMP)
  • Strategic Investment (SIP)
  • Emergency Medical Technician (EMT)
  • Z-School
  • Virtanza Tech Sales
  • Quickstart Affiliated Programs
  • Blockchain Academy
  • Intersectional Justice Facilitator
  • Environmental & Climate Advocacy, Leadership & Activism (ECALA)
  • CPA Licensure Prep Summer Program

UC Alumni Association Members and Retirees/Emeriti Discount

The Alumni Associations of the University of California (AAUC) offer members a 15% discount on professional course fees and academic courses offered by main campus. A 25% discount is also available to all UC Retirees and Emeriti. The discount must be requested at the time of enrollment and will not be applied retroactively. Online enrollment is not available to alumni, retirees, emeriti and affiliates who wish to use this discount and discounts are taken off the standard course fee. To receive your discount, please send an email with your phone number and email to help@professional.ucsb.edu. A member of our Customer Support team will contact you to arrange a convenient time to assist with enrollment.

UCSB Employee Discount

Employee discount on professional course fees and academic courses offered by main campus are provided to university staff and faculty in order to encourage campus employee professional and personal development.

UCSB faculty and staff who are employed at least 50% time in career positions are eligible to receive a 25% discount. In addition, spouses, domestic partners (as defined by UCSB for employee benefits), parents, and children of eligible faculty and staff may receive a 15% discount. Discounts must be requested at the time of enrollment (a copy of the staff ID card must accompany the enrollment), and will not be applied retroactively. Self-enrollment is not available to students wishing to use this discount. In order to receive the UCSB employee discount, the following must occur:

  1. Faculty and staff must provide proof of eligibility by sending a copy of a current UCSB staff card and a photo ID to help@professional.ucsb.edu. A member of our Customer Support Team will then contact you to assist with enrollment and payment.
  2. Departments paying fees through a recharge must contact UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE) to confirm the Department recharge account and the person authorizing the recharge prior to enrollment.

For any questions regarding the discounts listed here, please email us at help@professional.ucsb.edu and our Customer Service Team will be happy to assist you. Our office hours are Monday through Friday from 9am to 5pm PST.

Title: Do I get a UCSB ID card?
Body:
Do I get a UCSB ID card?

No. As a student of Open University through UCSB Professional and Continuing Education (PaCE), you will not receive an ID card. Because you will not pay campus-based fees, you will not have access to campus-based services, including the Rec Cen, childcare, financial aid, etc. However, you may pay for access to select services on a non-registered student basis.

Title: Certificate Eligibility and Requirements
Body:
Certificate Eligibility and Requirements

A certificate is awarded upon completion of the 4 required courses totaling 16 units (or 144 hours of instruction), listed in the Program Schedule each with a letter grade of "C" / "Pass" or better. All requirements must be completed within five (5) years after the student enrolls in their first course. Students not pursuing a certificate are welcome to take as many individual courses as they wish.

There are no prerequisites for courses in this certificate nor is a bachelor's degree required.

To become an official candidate in the program, students need only register in one of the courses in the approved curriculum.

Request for Certificate Release

Application Fee $45.00

If all the Certificate requirements have been met, after your request is processed, you will receive an email notification from Parchment with a digital copy of your Certificate. A printed copy will be mailed via regular US Postal Service to the mailing address provided in your PaCE Student Profile 8-10 business days after receipt of the digital copy.

The $45 Certificate Release Fee is non-refundable. This Fee is required in order to receive a copy of your Certificate.

Click here to request your Certificate Release.

Title: Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Business Accounting
Body:
Certificate Eligibility and Requirements - Business Accounting

A certificate is awarded upon completion of the 6 required courses totaling 24 units (or 216 hours of instruction), listed in the Program Schedule each with a letter grade of "C" / "Pass" or better. All requirements must be completed within five (5) years after the student enrolls in their first course. Students not pursuing a certificate are welcome to take as many individual courses as they wish.

The following are suggested prerequisites:

  • ECON X400A - Principles of Financial Accounting I
  • ECON X400B - Principles of Financial Accounting II

A bachelor's degree is not required.

To become an official candidate in the program, students need only register in one of the courses in the approved curriculum.

Request for Certificate Release

Application Fee $95.00

If all the Certificate requirements have been met, after your request is processed, you will receive an email notification from Parchment with a digital copy of your Certificate. A printed copy will be mailed via regular US Postal Service to the mailing address provided in your PaCE Student Profile 8-10 business days after receipt of the digital copy.

The $95 Certificate Release Fee is non-refundable. This Fee is required in order to receive a copy of your Certificate.

Click here to request your Certificate Release.

Title: How do I know when the courses are being offered?
Body:
How do I know when the courses are being offered?

The Program Course Schedule matrix on each certificate page indicates the current plan for course offerings, which are organized by academic quarter and location. The Division of Professional and Continuing Education offers courses four times a year during fall, winter, spring, and summer. For more about academic quarter dates, see the UCSB Academic Calendar.

Please note that the plan is subject to change based on course cancellations. For the most up-to-date information about course offerings and scheduled dates/times, read the specific course description.

Title: EMT Drop, Transfer and Withdrawal Policy
Body:
EMT Drop, Transfer and Withdrawal Policy

Dropping, Transferring and Withdrawing from your EMT class

You can request to drop from a course before the deadline (ALWAYS check the course page for specific drop policy stipulations and published deadlines). After the drop deadline, you can only ask for a withdrawal.

 

Refund Deadline:

A full refund is given (less a $75 administrative fee per course) if notice to drop from the course is received by PaCE by 11:59PM fifteen (15) or more days before the first session of class.

No refunds will be given if the request is received by 11:59PM fourteen (14) or less days before the first session of class.

In the event that a course is cancelled, students will receive a full refund.

 

How to drop from a class:

You have two easy options to request a drop from your course(s):

1) Submit a written drop request using our help request form.

2) Log in to your Student Portal, then: Navigate to "My Enrollment History (Current Courses) " and select the course you would like to drop. On the right side, under "Actions and Status," select "Request Drop". 

You will receive an email confirmation within 1-2 business days after your drop request is processed.

 

Transfer Deadline:

If you wish to transfer from one section to another, you may do so at no cost if the request is received 15 or more days before the section start date.

If the request is received 14 or fewer days before the section start date, no transfer will be allowed.

 

How to transfer from one section to another:

You must submit a request in writing by using our help request form. Please include the course/section ID number you would like to transfer from and the course/section ID number you would like to transfer to. If the transfer results in a balance due, we will contact you for payment before processing your request. Any difference in course fees is assessed and due at the time of the transfer.

 

How to withdraw from a class:

If you wish to withdraw from your EMT course, you may do so until the last class session by notifying PaCE by using our help request form. 

 

Exceptions:

All requests for exceptions must be submitted in writing by using our help request form.  Be sure to attach any supporting documents (such as a doctor's note).

Title: Do I need to have car insurance?
Body:
Do I need to have car insurance?

Yes. According to California law, the owner of a car must maintain insurance coverage. The minimum insurance coverage required by law is called "liability." Liability coverage pays, up to certain limits, the sum for which you become legally responsible if you injure someone or damage their car. Car insurance can cost between $55-95 a month, for a minimum of six months (cost may vary depending on driver's characteristics and driving history). Other types of coverage are optional and are as follows:

  • Uninsured motorist:
    • Protects you and your passengers if you are injured by an uninsured or hit-and-run driver, but only if the other driver is legally liable because of negligent driving. (Note that some insurance companies automatically include this coverage in their policies.)
  • Collision:
    • Pays for your losses if your car is damaged in a collision or single car accident. This coverage is valuable if the collision cannot be proven to be someone else's fault.
  • Comprehensive:
    • Pays for your loss if your car is stolen or damaged by fire, hail, hurricane, vandalism, or most other non-collision causes.

For help choosing car insurance, you may want to contact an insurance agent or broker. An insurance agent works exclusively for one insurance company. A broker or independent insurance agent works with many different insurance companies and policies and can compare different rates for you. Before you purchase insurance, make sure the agent/broker and insurer you select are licensed by the California Department of Insurance (1-800-927-4357).

Title: Certificate Eligibility and Requirements
Body:
Certificate Eligibility and Requirements

A certificate is awarded upon completion of the 7 required courses totaling 13 units (or 117 hours of instruction), listed in the Program Schedule each with a letter grade of "C" / "Pass" or better. All requirements must be completed within five (5) years after the student enrolls in his/her first course. Students not pursuing a certificate are welcome to take as many individual courses as they wish.

 

There are no prerequisites for courses in this certificate nor is a bachelor's degree required.

 

To become an official candidate in the program, students need only register in one of the courses in the approved curriculum.

Title: Student Conduct
Body:
Student Conduct

UCSB Professional and Continuing Education affirms an instructor's right to teach in a controlled, positive learning environment. Our policy on student conduct upholds that right and also ensures due process for students. When you are a student, you are expected to demonstrate a commitment to academic integrity and to civic responsibility.

Students are subject to disciplinary action for several types of misconduct, such as cheating on exams, forgery, theft, destruction of property, disruption of classes, physical or verbal abuse of others, sexual harassment, and possession of alcohol, drugs, or firearms. Actions may include, but are not limited to, dismissal and denial of enrollment in future UCSB Professional and Continuing Education classes.

Title: Can I complete the whole program online?
Body:
Can I complete the whole program online?

Yes, all coursework is offered through Canvas, UCSB online learning management system. You do not need any additional software. The courses are offered in an asynchronous format, which means you do not need to be at your computer on any particular date/time. You have weekly assignments with a due date and must interact with your classmates through discussion forums.

Title: Instructor Portal/Grading Instructions
Body:
Instructor Portal/Grading Instructions

INSTRUCTOR LOGIN
To log in, visit our homepage and then click on Login in the upper right-hand corner and select Instructor Login from the dropdown menu.

Enter your Username and Password. Your User Name is your PaCE Instructor ID (not your employee number). If you do not know your PaCE Instructor ID, please contact us at help@professional.ucsb.edu.

If you do not know this information, use the Forgot User Name and or the Forgot Password links to have the information emailed to the address you used on your bio-form.

Your email account will be the one you included in the instructor bio-form. 

INSTRUCTOR PORTAL

Once logged in to your Instructor Portal, you can choose from the following options in the menu on the left-hand side:

- My Profile - Review/make changes to your profile.
- Courses - Access information on the courses you teach
- Current Schedule - Review your course schedule. 
- Forms and Policies - Find information on policies
- Announcements - Typically, class announcements are made through e-mail and not through the portal.
- Help - Request Help 

Clicking the Courses link brings you to the courses tab, which lists courses you have taught and are currently teaching.

For course details, click on the hyperlink of the course section number. 


Clicking on a particular course takes you to the class list. From this page you can select:
- Grading Sheet for entering grades. 
- Course Profile to find room assignments, course descriptions, and learning outcomes.


At the bottom of the Class List page you can: 

- Print Class List
- Print Attendance Sheet
- Email Selected Students during the quarter. 
- E-mail All students to welcome them to the class or send class updates

To enter grades click Grading Sheet:
1. Scroll down to the Class List section and click the student name box.
2. Select grade from the Final Grade(T) pull-down menu.
3. Select the completion date.
4. Click the Instructor Approved box. 

5. Click Save at the bottom of the page. This submits the grades.

Title: Where do EMTs work?
Body:
Where do EMTs work?

Many professions require or prefer EMT trained employees. Examples include: ambulance services, hospital emergency departments, fire departments, lifeguards, US Forest Service, ski patrol, security companies, industrial complexes and volunteer service organizations such as Search and Rescue. It is also valuable for those who are responsible for individuals or groups.

Title: GauchoCast and Panopto Training Resources
Body:
GauchoCast and Panopto Training Resources

GauchoCast and Panopto 

  • Enables the recording, editing, and distribution of streaming audio and video content on the web.
  • Provides for lecture capture with multiple inputs (e.g. lecture audio, synchronized PowerPoint/Keynote slides, document camera, demonstration camera) with the Panopto recording software installed. 
  • Allows faculty members to record their own in-office instructional podcasts for later online distribution.

 

Please log in using your GauchoSpace credentials, not Panopto credentials. Please select GauchoSpace from the drop-down menu instead of Panopto. Click sign-in and this will redirect you to GauchoSpace where you may sign-in using SSO.
